(c)  Subject to any applicable restrictions of law or restrictions of any bonds or bond issue, amendments which do not require supplemental appropriations, but which involve additions or deletions of projects or in the case of the capital improvement program an increase in the aggregate amount thereof, may be made without requirement of a public hearing by a majority of all of the members of city council at the same meeting at which such amendment is introduced. 
(Ord. No. 1852, 4-17-89; Ord. No. 2255, 1-25-94; Ord. No. 2324, 5-9-95)  
Secs. 2-200—2-205. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - DIRECTOR OF FINANCE[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Charter reference— Director of finance, § 8.02. 
 
Sec. 2-206. - General powers and duties. 
The director of finance shall be the administrative head of the department of finance and as such shall have charge of the financial affairs of the city, including such powers and duties as may be assigned to the director of finance, or department of finance, by order or resolution of the council or orders of the city manager not inconsistent with the Constitution and general laws of the state. 
(Code 1965, § 2-108) 
Charter reference— Department of finance created, § 7.01; composition of department of finance, § 8.01.  
Sec. 2-207. - Compilation of budget estimates. 
The director of finance shall cooperate with the city manager in compiling estimates for the current expense and capital budgets. 
(Code 1965, § 2-109) 
Charter reference— Budget, Ch. 5.  
Sec. 2-208. - Approval and supervision of disbursement of expenditures. 
(a)  The director of finance shall approve all proposed expenditures and, unless he shall certify that there is an unencumbered balance of appropriated and available funds, no expenditures shall be made. 
(b)  The director of finance shall supervise and be responsible for the disbursement of all expenditures to ensure that budget appropriations are not exceeded. 
(c)  The director of finance shall not expend any funds for the construction of, or additions to capital facilities without the project having been authorized by ordinance of the city council. 
(Code 1965, §§ 2-110, 2-114; Ord. No. 1246, 1-11-82; 1337, 10-25-82; Ord. No. 1340, 11-8-82)  
Sec. 2-208.1. - Reasonable charges for the reissuance of paperwork and checks. 
(a)  The director of finance or designee shall impose the following fees for additional services to recover the reasonable administrated costs associated with each activity: 
(1)  Fifteen dollars ($15.00) for the reissuance of a check that was lost and requires reissuance not due to the fault of the city; 
(2)  Fifteen dollars ($15.00) for the holding of a check for pick-up in lieu of mailing; 
(3)  Fifteen dollars ($15.00) for the reissuance of an IRS Form 1099 that was lost and requires reissuance not due to the fault of the city. 
(b)  The charges provided in subsection (a) shall not apply to the reissuance or pick-up of checks issued as part of the city's employee payroll activities. 
(c)  The director of finance is hereby authorized to waive the charge imposed by this section, provided such waiver shall be pursuant to a written policy approved by the director of finance and made available on the city's website. 
(Ord. No. 3177, 5-10-11; Ord. No. 3383, 11-25-14)  
Sec. 2-209. - Accounts and accounting. 
The director of finance shall maintain a general accounting system in conformity with accepted principles of governmental accounting for the city government and each of its offices, departments and agencies; keep books for, and exercise financial budgetary control over each office, department and agency; and keep separate accounts for the items of appropriation contained in the appropriation ordinance, each of which accounts shall show the amount of appropriation, the amounts paid therefrom, the unpaid obligations against it and the unencumbered balance. Additional accounts for classification of expenditures shall be maintained to provide adequate information for budgetary purposes. 
(Code 1965, § 2-111)  
Sec. 2-210. - Periodic financial statements. 
The director of finance shall submit to the city manager and the council, at least monthly, or more frequently if required, financial statements in sufficient detail to show the exact financial condition of the city. 
(Code 1965, § 2-112)  
Sec. 2-211. - Annual financial statement and report. 
The director of finance shall prepare for the city manager, as of the end of each fiscal year, a complete financial statement and report. 
(Code 1965, § 2-113) 
Charter reference— Annual audit, § 8.06.  
Sec. 2-212. - Audit of claims for goods or services. 
The director of finance shall audit all claims against the city for goods or services for the purpose of ascertaining that such claims are in accordance with the purchase orders or contracts of employment from which the same arise. 
(Code 1965, § 2-115)  
Sec. 2-213. - Responsibility as to insurance and risk management programs; investigation; settlement and adjustment of claims against city. 
(a)  The director of finance shall be responsible for the development, administration and operation of the city's corporate insurance, self-insurance and risk management programs. 
(b)  The director of finance or his duly authorized representative shall have the authority to investigate, adjust, compromise and settle claims and to authorize the investigation, adjustment, compromise and settlement of claims against the city. Any payment for investigation, adjustment, compromise and/or settlement of claims against the city shall be taken from the self-insurance fund and other funds provided by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1112, 10-27-80; Ord. No. 1716, 7-13-87) 
Charter reference— Notice of claims for damages against city, § 9.04.  
DIVISION 2.5. - PROCUREMENT[11]

Sec. 2-214. - Establishment and composition of division of purchasing. 
There is hereby established, within the department of finance, a division of purchasing, which shall consist of the purchasing agent and such other officers and employees as may be provided by ordinance or by orders or directives consistent therewith. 
(Ord. No. 1353, 1-3-83)  
Sec. 2-214.1. - Purchasing authority. 
(a)  The purchasing division of the department of finance shall be responsible for the purchase or lease of all goods, and the purchase of all services and construction, for all city departments and agencies exclusive of the city school system. In addition, the division shall be responsible for centralized control and disposal of excess, obsolete and salvageable materials and equipment. In the event that a surplus vehicle is sold and the original title transferred had been lost not due to the fault of the city, the director of finance or designee shall impose a fee for additional services to recover the administrative costs associated with the reissuance of the vehicle(s) title in the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00) per reissued title. 
(b)  No officer or employee of the city government has the authority to contract for the procurement of materials, supplies, equipment or services except the city purchasing agent or such other employee as may be designated by the city manager or city council. 
(Ord. No. 1353, 1-3-83; Ord. No. 2480, 4-7-98; Ord. No. 3176, § 1, 5-10-11)  
Sec. 2-214.2. - Duties, powers, and responsibilities of purchasing agent. 
(a)  The purchasing agent shall be the head of the purchasing division and under the supervision of the director of finance. 
(b)  The purchasing agent shall have the power and it shall be his duty to: 
(1)  Endeavor to obtain as full and open competition as possible and practicable on all purchases and sales through competitive sealed bidding, or through any other method of procurement authorized by this division of chapter 2; 
(2)  Except where established by ordinance or resolution of council, establish such rules, regulations and policies as he/she deems necessary for the internal management and operation of the purchasing division; and 
(3)  Delegate to individual departments, as he or she deems appropriate, the authority to directly purchase goods or services as provided for and limited by Code of Virginia § 2.2-4303(G) and (H), including future amendments thereto; provided the department uses competition wherever practicable and complies with all applicable rules, regulations, policies, procedures and administrative directives pertaining to procurement. 
(c)  All formal rules, regulations, policies, procedures and administrative directives pertaining to procurement shall be subject to the approval of the city manager and the purchasing agent, and shall be approved by the city attorney as to form and legality. 
(d)  Subject to compliance with all applicable policies, procedures, and city code provisions pertaining to contract execution, the purchasing agent shall have the authority to award contracts within the purview of this division. 
(e)  It shall be the responsibility of the purchasing division to obtain as full and open competition as possible and practical on all purchases and sales through competitive sealed bidding, or through any other method of procurement authorized by this or other sections. 
(Ord. No. 1353, 1-3-83; Ord. No. 2480, 4-7-98; Ord. No. 2716, 8-6-02)  
Sec. 2-214.3. - Adoption of designated sections of Virginia Public Procurement Act. 
(a)  Pursuant to section 2.2-4302 of the Code of Virginia, as amended, the following sections of the Virginia Public Procurement Act [Code of Virginia, title 2.2, chapter 43], and any future amendments thereto, are hereby adopted and incorporated by reference into this code: 2.2-4301, 2.2-4343(B), 2.2-4304(A), 2.2-4303, 2.2-4305, 2.2-4308, 2.2-4319, 2.2-4331, 2.2-4310(A), 2.2-4320, 2.2-4344(A)(1), 2.2-4309(B), 2.2-4344(A)(2), 2.2-4344(B), 2.2-4345(A)(14), 2.2-4345(A)(13) and 2.2-4344(C), 2.2-4317, 2.2-4332, 2.2-4324, 2.2-4328, 2.2-4315 through 2.2-4350(B), 2.2-4353, 2.2-4349, 2.2-4354 through 2.2-4377. 
(b)  Notwithstanding subsection (a) of this section, whenever any provision of the Virginia Public Procurement Act which has been adopted and incorporated by reference herein is modified or amended by any other section of this code, or by any rule, regulation, policy, procedure or administrative directive, such provision shall be interpreted and implemented as modified or amended. 
(Ord. No. 2480, 4-7-98; Ord. No. 2716, 8-6-02)  
Sec. 2-215. - Submission of bids and proposals. 
(a)  Bids and proposals shall be submitted to the purchasing division in a sealed envelope, shall be clearly marked or identified as specified in the invitation to bid or request for proposals, and shall be opened in public at the time and place stated in the invitation to bid or request for proposals. 
(b)  Every bid and proposal shall contain an anticollusion statement which shall be sworn to by each bidder or offeror. 
(Ord. No. 1353, 1-3-83; Ord. No. 1462, 7-2-84; Ord. No. 1721, 8-3-87; Ord. No. 2201, 1-12-93; Ord. No. 2480, 4-7-98)  
Sec. 2-215.1. - Reserved. 
Note— See the second paragraph of the editor's note to Div. 2.5.  
Sec. 2-215.2. - Emergency purchases. 
(a)  An emergency shall be defined as a situation in which (i) an immediate threat to the public health, safety or welfare is involved, or (ii) immediate action is required to protect or preserve public properties. 
(b)  In case of an emergency during normal working hours which requires immediate purchase of supplies or contractual services, the purchasing agent shall have the authority to secure, by the open market procedure, at the lowest obtainable price, any supplies or contractual services, regardless of the amount of the expenditure. A full report of the circumstances of an emergency purchase so made shall be filed by the purchasing agent. 
(c)  In case of an emergency, not within normal working hours, the purchasing agent may authorize the head of any city department to purchase directly any supplies, the immediate procurement of which is essential to prevent delays in the work of the department which may vitally affect the public health, safety or welfare, or to protect or preserve public properties without delay. The head of such department shall send to the purchasing agent a requisition and a copy of the delivery record, together with a full written report of the circumstances of the emergency. The report shall be filed by the purchasing agent. 
(d)  In all cases of emergency purchases, the using agency shall submit a written report to the purchasing agent, signed by the department head, detailing the aspects of the emergency. The written report shall be accompanied by a requisition form. Upon receipt of such written report, the purchasing agent shall solicit pricing in a manner consistent with the emergency situation and shall issue a confirming purchase order. 
(Ord. No. 1353, 1-3-83; Ord. No. 1462, 7-2-84; Ord. No. 2201, 1-12-93; Ord. No. 2480, 4-7-98)  
Sec. 2-215.3. - Reserved. 
Note— See the second paragraph of the editor's note to Div. 2.5.  
Sec. 2-216. - Bidder's list. 
The purchasing agent shall maintain a bidder's list containing the names of all responsible prospective suppliers who have requested suppliers who have requested their names to be included on such lists. The purchasing agent, where deemed necessary, can require these requests to be made in writing and may require any additional literature or references as he may feel pertinent. 
(Ord. No. 1353, 1-3-83)  
Sec. 2-216.1. - Debarment. 
(a)  Pursuant to section 2.2-4321 of the Code of Virginia, the purchasing agent shall have the authority to debar any prospective contractor from contracting for particular types of goods, services, insurance or construction for a specified period of time, and to remove any such contractor from the bidders' lists when the public interest will be best served thereby. This may be caused by any contractor's unsatisfactory performance, including defaulting on its quotations or contracts, or by any other behavior on the part of a contractor which is deemed by the purchasing agent to be unethical, harmful to the city, or in any other way not to the best interest of the city. 
(b)  Reasons for such debarment and removal shall be outlined in writing by the purchasing agent and sent by certified or registered mail to the contractor so debarred and removed at least ten (10) days prior to the date set for receipt of bids or proposals. 
(Ord. No. 1353, 1-3-83; Ord. No. 2480, 4-7-98; Ord. No. 2716, 8-6-02)  
Sec. 2-216.2. - Reserved. 
Note— See the second paragraph of the editor's note to Div. 2.5.  
Sec. 2-217. - Specifications for purchases. 
(a)  Where at all possible, detailed, definite specifications will be used for purchases. However, in instances in which trade names and model numbers are used to designate the quality of the merchandise desired, it is always specified that an alternate of equal or better quality may be proposed. The decision of approval of all alternates shall be between the purchasing division and the using department. The burden of proving that an alternate is equal shall rest with the vendor. 
(b)  Written comments from prospective bidders (vendors) concerning specifications or alternatives may be accepted by the purchasing agent for consideration if submitted at least ten (10) days prior to the date set for receipt of bids. 
(Ord. No. 1353, 1-3-83)

Sec. 2-224.1. - Definitions. 
For purposes of this subsection, the following words shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section: 
Good-faith participation efforts: The sum total of efforts by a particular bidder to provide for the equitable participation of SWaM-certified small business subcontractors in response to a city procurement. 
Minority, service disabled veteran and woman contractors bid list: A list of contractors who have completed and filed with the purchasing agent the city's bidder application indicating that their firm is a minority-owned, service disabled veteran or woman-owned business. The purchasing agent shall maintain the list and shall organize the list by category of business. Such list shall be provided, upon request, in its entirety or by relevant category, to any interested party. The list shall not be deemed to constitute an endorsement of the qualifications of any business included on the list. 
Minority-owned business: A business or other entity that is at least fifty-one (51) percent owned and controlled by one (1) or more socially and economically disadvantaged person(s). For purposes of this definition, the term "control" shall mean exercising the power to make policy decisions and being actively involved in day-to-day management. Such disadvantage may arise from cultural, racial, chronic economic circumstance or background, or other similar cause. Such persons include, but are not limited to, Black Americans, Hispanic Americans, Asian Americans, Eskimos, and Aleuts. 
Prime contractor workforce composition form means a document providing the following information: The composition of the contractor's workforce, specifically indicating the percentage of woman, service disabled veteran and minority employees in their company; the percentage of woman, service disabled veteran and minorities in management positions, supervisory positions, professional positions, and nonprofessional positions 
Service disabled veteran: means a veteran who (i) served on active duty in the United States military ground, naval, or air service, (ii) was discharged or released under conditions other than dishonorable, and (iii) has a service-connected disability rating fixed by the United States Department of Veterans Affairs. 
Service disabled veteran business: means a business concern that is at least fifty-one (51) percent owned by one or more service disabled veterans or, in the case of a corporation, partnership, or limited liability company or other entity, at least fifty-one (51) percent of the equity ownership interest in the corporation, partnership, or limited liability company or other entity is owned by one or more individuals who are service disabled veterans and both the management and daily business operations are controlled by one or more individuals who are service disabled veterans. 
Small business means a business, independently owned and controlled by one or more individuals who are U.S. citizens or legal resident aliens, and together with affiliates, has two hundred fifty (250) or fewer employees, or annual gross receipts of ten million dollars ($10,000,000.00) or less averaged over the previous three (3) years. One or more of the individual owners shall control both the management and daily business operations of the small business. 
SWaM-certified small business means a small business that has been certified by the Virginia Department of Small Business and Supplier Diversity or a successor department of the Commonwealth. SWaM-certified small business may also mean a business that has been certified by the City's small business office. 
SWaM-certified small business subcontracting participation plan: A plan detailing, at a minimum: Whether the contractor intends to utilize any subcontractors; what, if any, SWaM-certified small business subcontractors the contractor intends to utilize; the work to be performed by each SWaM-certified small business subcontractor; and the anticipated amount or percentage to be paid to each SWaM-certified small business. SWaM-certified small businesses include small businesses that are SWaM-certified as being minority owned, woman owned, or disabled veteran owned. Prime contractors are strongly encouraged to utilize minority contractors as part of their overall small business subcontracting plan. The city council has established a goal of ten (10) percent minority-owned business participation in city contracts. 
Specificity means sufficient information necessary to enable the City staff to substantiate or confirm the matter asserted. For example, "specificity" in the context of a quote requires at a minimum, the following information: the firm providing the quote: the contract person or representative for the quote; the date the quote was provided; and the scope of work attributed to such quote. 
Woman-owned business: A business or other entity that is at least fifty-one (51) percent owned and controlled by a woman or women. For purposes of this definition, the term "control" shall mean exercising the power to make policy decisions and being actively involved in day-to-day management. 
(Ord. No. 2309, 2-28-95; Ord. No. 2935, 4-4-06; Ord. No. 3088, 6-23-09; Ord. No. 3203, § 3, 9-27-11; Ord. No. 3344, 4-22-14; Ord. No. 3627, § 2, 6-16-20)  
Sec. 2-224.2. - Process to determine sufficiency of good faith efforts. 
When a subcontracting participation plan does not provide the fifty (50) percent SWaM-certified participation requirement set forth in 2-224.6(b)(i) and a responsiveness determination is required pursuant to 2-224.6(b)(ii), the determination of whether the materials submitted with the bid satisfy the "good-faith" requirement is a question of fact to be rendered by the purchasing agent. The following factors are relevant to such determination: 
(1)  What steps the bidder has taken to solicit and negotiate subcontracting bids from SWaM-certified small businesses; 
(2)  Whether the bidder utilized the city outreach list, if applicable; 
(3)  Whether the bidder debundled or right-sized project components to allow for meaningful small business participation; 
(4)  Whether the bidder provided assistance in bonding, insurance, equipment, supplies, or other assistance or services; 
(5)  Whether the bidder has taken other steps to identify and engage small businesses that would be willing and able to perform the subcontracted work; and 
(6)  Whether the efforts undertaken by the bidder appear to be reasonably calculated to lead to the maximization of SWaM-certified small business participation. 
The review of the above factors should identify the reasons why the fifty (50) percent SWaM-certified small business subcontracting requirement was not met. If the purchasing agent is satisfied that the documentation submitted with the bid evidences the bidder made a good faith effort to provide for the equitable participation of SWaM-certified small business in the procurement, the purchasing agent shall memorialize such determination in the bid file. If the purchasing agent is unable to make such determination, the rationale for such determination shall be communicated to the bidder at the time of posting intent to award. 
(Ord. No. 3344, 4-22-14)  
Sec. 2-224.3. - SWaM-certified small business, including woman and minority-owned business opportunities—Construction contracts; bid requirements. 
(a)  Notice of every invitation to bid on city construction contracts in excess of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) shall be provided to all SWaM-certified small businesses in the relevant industry sector located within fifty (50) miles of the city. In addition, the purchasing agent shall also forward such notices, upon request, to any minority organization or other interested party. 
(b)  If a pre-bid meeting is held, the purchasing agent or designee shall provide prospective contractors with direction regarding the resources for locating SWaM-certified small businesses offered by the Virginia Department of Minority Business Enterprises or successor department. 
(c)  Every bid submitted in response to an invitation to bid on a city construction contract in excess of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) shall be required to contain a proposed SWaM-certified small business subcontracting participation plan. 
(d)  The purchasing agent shall provide, upon request, to all prospective prime construction contractors, a list of all businesses included in the relevant categories of the minority, service disabled veteran and woman contractors bid list; provided, however, that the list shall not be deemed to include all available minority-owned or woman-owned subcontractors, nor shall it be deemed to constitute an endorsement of the qualifications of any subcontractor included on the list. 
(e)  For purposes of this section, "bid" shall include a request for proposals ("RFP") for construction, where permitted, design-build proposals, construction manager at risk contracts, and PPEA proposals (Detail Phase) for construction. 
(f)  Prior to contract execution and provided the bidder meets the requirements of this section and section 2-224.6, the bidder shall be afforded the opportunity to update or validate the subcontracting plan in the ten (10) days after the posting of notice of intent to award. This update or validation will not be accepted if it substantially decreases the utilization, either by dollar amount or percentage, of subcontracted work to SWaM-certified small business subcontractors. The final SWaM-certified small business subcontracting participation plan shall become a part of the contract with the city. 
(Ord. No. 2309, 2-28-95; Ord. No. 2935, 4-4-06; Ord. No. 3088, 6-23-09; Ord. No. 3203, § 3, 9-27-11; Ord. No. 3344, 4-22-14)  
Sec. 2-224.4. - Same—Contracts for provision of goods and services. 
Solicitations for goods and services contracts of more than fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) shall include at least three (3) SWaM-certified small businesses, including minority-owned businesses, service disabled veteran-owned businesses or woman-owned businesses that are included on the list maintained pursuant to section 2-224.1 and are in the business of supplying goods or services of the kind to be procured, unless the list of available SWaM-certified vendors contains less than three (3) such businesses. In addition, the purchasing agent shall forward such solicitations, upon request, to any minority organization or other interested party. 
(Ord. No. 2309, 2-28-95; Ord. No. 2935, 4-4-06; Ord. No. 3088, 6-23-09; Ord. No. 3203, § 3, 9-27-11; Ord. No. 3344, 4-22-14)  
Sec. 2-224.5. - Same—Procurement of professional and other than professional services by competitive negotiation. 
(a)  Notice of every request for proposals ("RFP") for professional services shall be provided to all SWaM-certified small businesses in the relevant industry sector located within fifty (50) miles of the city. In addition, the purchasing agent shall also forward such notices, upon request, to any minority organization or other interested party. 
(b)  If a pre-bid meeting is held, the purchasing agent or designee shall provide prospective contractors with direction regarding the resources for locating SWaM-certified small businesses offered by the Virginia Department of Minority Business Enterprises or successor department. 
(c)  To the extent practicable, the submitted proposal should provide possible subconsultants and subcontractors that the offeror intends to utilize in the execution of the services and whether such firms are SWaM-certified. 
(Ord. No. 2309, 2-28-95; Ord. No. 2935, 4-4-06; Ord. No. 3088, 6-23-09; Ord. No. 3203, § 3, 9-27-11; Ord. No. 3344, 4-22-14)  
Sec. 2-224.6. - Responsible and responsive bidder; qualified offeror. 
(a)  The provisions of this subdivision shall be used as criteria in determining whether a bidder is deemed to be responsible and responsive and no contract shall be awarded to a bidder who has not complied with the provisions herein. Failure to submit a proposed SWaM-certified small business subcontracting participation plan or sufficient documentation of good-faith participation efforts with a bid shall result in the bid being declared nonresponsive. 
(b)  For construction contracts with a value exceeding fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) where the contractor intends to utilize subcontractors, the SWaM-certified small business subcontracting participation plan required by this article must either: (i) provide for at least fifty (50) percent of the value of the subcontracted work to be provided by one or more SWaM-certified small businesses; or (ii) provide documentation showing, with specificity, the good-faith participation efforts undertaken by the prospective contractor to attempt to meet the fifty (50) percent usage requirement. In fulfilling the fifty percent SWaM-certified small business subcontracting requirement, prime contractors are strongly encouraged to utilize minority-owned businesses as subcontractors. 
(c)  If a subcontracting plan does not meet the requirements of subsection (b), the entire bid or proposal shall be declared nonresponsive to the solicitation. 
(Ord. No. 2309, 2-28-95; Ord. No. 2935, 4-4-06; Ord. No. 3088, 6-23-09; Ord. No. 3203, § 3, 9-27-11; Ord. 3344, 4-22-14)  
Sec. 2-224.7. - Public inspection of records. 
In accordance with the Virginia Freedom of Information Act, a bidder's or contractor's Woman, Service Disabled Veteran and Minority Participation Plan shall be open to public inspection. 
(Ord. No. 2309, 2-28-95; Ord. No. 2935, 4-4-06; Ord. No. 3088, 6-23-09)  
Sec. 2-224.8. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any bidder or contractor that intentionally makes a material misrepresentation in connection with any of the information required by subdivision shall be debarred from contracting with the city for a period of two (2) years from the date of notification of such debarment. 
(b)  Prior to final payment, each contractor shall submit a report documenting its efforts undertaken in compliance with its final SWaM-certified small business subcontracting participation plan. The report shall include, at a minimum: A statement of whether any SWaM-certified small business subcontractors were utilized; a list of any SWaM-certified small businesses; a brief description of the work performed by each SWaM-certified small business; the amount paid to each SWaM-certified small business; and any additional good-faith minority-owned, service disabled veteran-owned and woman-owned business participation efforts the contractor made in connection with the contract. A contractor will not receive final payment under a contract until he submits the documentation required by this subsection. 
(c)  If actual woman, service disabled veteran and minority participation substantially deviates below the levels outlined in the final SWaM-certified small business subcontracting participation plan, the contractor shall provide an explanation for the deviation within ten (10) days of a request by the city for such explanation. If the explanation for the deviation lacks reasonable justification that rises to the level of dishonesty or in the event the contractor refuses to submit an explanation for the deviation, the contractor may be debarred from contracting with the city for a period of up to two (2) years from the date of notification of such debarment. 
(d)  The debarment of any bidder or contractor pursuant to this subdivision shall be deemed to include the debarment of any successor corporation, partnership, firm or other entity controlled or managed by any officer, director, partner or controlling shareholder of the debarred bidder or contractor. 
(Ord. No. 2309, 2-28-95; Ord. No. 2935, 4-4-06; Ord. No. 3088, 6-23-09; Ord. No. 3203, § 3, 9-27-11; Ord. No. 3344, 4-22-14)  
Sec. 2-224.9. - Minority business council composition; appointment and terms of members, etc. 
(a)  The City of Virginia Beach Minority Business Council shall consist of at least nine (9) but not more than eleven (11) members. 
(b)  The members of the minority business council shall be appointed by the city council for terms of two (2) years; provided, however, that the initial terms of several members may be for one year in order to allow for staggered expirations of the terms of members. Of those members appointed, one member may be a member of city council. 
(c)  The meeting in June of each year shall be the annual organizational meeting at which the minority business council shall elect, from among its members, a chair and vice-chair. The chair and vice-chair shall each serve for a term of one year, or until his or her respective successor has been elected. Both the chair and the vice-chair may be re-elected; provided, however, that no member shall serve more than four (4) consecutive one-year terms in the same office. 
(d)  Attendance records shall be kept at each meeting of the minority business council, and an annual report of attendance shall be submitted to city council through the city clerk's office. No member shall accumulate an annual total of (i) more than three (3) absences or (ii) absences exceeding one-fourth of the number of meetings held, whichever is lesser, for reasons other than personal illness, death or other unusual circumstances. If this limitation is exceeded, the chairperson shall report to the city clerk the name of the minority business council member whose unexcused absences exceed the number set forth herein. The city clerk shall then notify such member in writing, with copies to the city council, that, due to absences in excess of the number allowed herein, his or her membership is terminated. Thereafter, the city clerk shall forward the vacancy to the city council for appointment of a new minority business council member to serve for the remainder of such terminated member's term. 
(e)  Notwithstanding the provisions of subsections (b) and (d) of this section, all members of the minority business council shall serve at the pleasure of city council. 
(Ord. No. 2310, 2-28-95; Ord. No. 2478, 3-10-98; Ord. No. 2841, 10-5-04; Ord. No. 3126, 4-27-10)  
Sec. 2-224.10. - Staff assistance; recordation of minutes. 
The city's purchasing agent shall serve in an advisory capacity to the minority business council and, among other duties, shall assist the chairperson of the minority business council in the preparation of meeting agendas. 
(Ord. No. 2310, 2-28-95)  
Sec. 2-224.11. - Duties, powers and functions. 
The minority business council shall serve as an advisory agency to the city manager and the city council with respect to the city's procurement policies and procedures and shall be vested with the following duties, powers and functions: 
(1)  To advise the city manager and the city council on policy and procedural issues involved in: 
a.  The city's established policy of equal opportunity and nondiscrimination in procurement; 
b.  The city's continuing efforts to encourage the participation of minority-owned businesses, small businesses, businesses owned by women, and businesses owned by service disabled veterans in city contracts; and 
c.  The city's assurance that its procurement opportunities are made available to all persons, regardless of race, religion, color, sex, national origin or handicap. 
(2)  To institute, conduct, and engage in educational and training programs to promote the involvement of minority-owned businesses, small businesses, businesses owned by women, and businesses owned by service disabled veterans in the public procurement process. 
(3)  To serve as a forum for the discussion and development of the awareness of minority-owned businesses, small businesses, businesses owned by women, and businesses owned by service disabled veterans of the procurement process. 
(4)  To provide city council and the city manager with an annual written report of the minority business council's activities on or before December thirty-first of each year. 
(5)  To adopt rules and procedures for the conduct of its affairs. 
The minority business council shall not be empowered or authorized to provide advice or assistance with respect to, or otherwise become involved in, individual procurement solicitations, evaluations, awards, disputes or protests. 
(Ord. No. 2309, 2-28-95; Ord. No. 2935, 4-4-06; Ord. No. 3088, 6-23-09)  
Sec. 2-224.12. - Sheltered bidding—Construction. 
(a)  For a solicitation to purchase construction services with an expected value of not more than five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) nor less than twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00), the purchasing agent shall review the anticipated scope of work to make a determination as to whether there are at least three (3) SWaM-certified small businesses willing and able to participate in the procurement solicitation. If the purchasing agent finds there are at least three (3) SWaM-certified small businesses willing and able, the purchasing agent shall document this finding in writing in the bid file. 
(b)  If the finding described in subsection (a) has been made, the invitation to bid shall limit the bidding to SWaM-certified small businesses. In addition to the customary notification methods, the invitation to bid shall be sent to the list of SWaM-certified small businesses maintained by the purchasing division for the relevant contracting classification or trade group. If such invitation to bid results in less than two (2) responsive bids, the purchasing agent shall cancel the invitation to bid and repeat the bidding process without the SWaM-certified small business limitation. 
(c)  The requirements of this section shall not apply to emergency procurements. 
(Ord. No. 3617, § 2, 6-16-20)  
Sec. 2-224.13. - Sheltered bidding—Goods and services. 
(a)  For a solicitation to purchase of goods or nonprofessional services with an expected value of not more than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) nor less than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), the purchasing agent shall review the anticipated scope of work to make a determination as to whether there are at least three (3) SWaM-certified small businesses willing and able to participate in the procurement solicitation. If the purchasing agent finds there are at least three (3) SWaM-certified small businesses willing and able, the purchasing agent shall document this finding in writing in the bid file. 
(b)  If the finding described in subsection (a) has been made, the invitation to bid or request for proposals shall limit the bidding to SWaM-certified small businesses. In addition to the customary notification methods, the invitation to bid shall be sent to the list of SWaM-certified small businesses maintained by the purchasing division for the relevant vendor type. If such invitation to bid or request for proposals results in less than two (2) responsive bids, the purchasing agent shall cancel the invitation to bid or request for proposals and repeat the bidding process without the SWaM-certified small business limitation. 
(c)  The requirements of this section shall not apply to emergency procurements or cooperative procurements. 
(Ord. No. 3617, § 2, 6-16-20)  
Sec. 2-224.14. - Project goals—Construction. 
(a)  For a solicitation to purchase construction services with an estimated value of more than five million dollars ($5,000,000.00), the purchasing agent or designee shall review the anticipated scope of work to make a determination as to whether there are sufficient subcontracting opportunities for meaningful minority-owned business project goals. In the setting of a project goal, the term "minority-owned business" shall mean only businesses owned by Asian Americans, Black Americans, and Hispanic Americans. In the development of the solicitation, the purchasing agent or designee in consultation with the city's SWaM Business Office shall use the same or substantially similar goal-setting methodology as is utilized in the federal Urban Construction Initiative. 
(b)  The project goal for the solicitation shall be a requirement for a responsive bid. Alternatively, a bidder may seek a waiver from the project goal requirement by submission of good faith efforts. The review of the request for a waiver shall use the same factors as set forth in section 2-224.2. Any determination of good faith efforts as a waiver shall be reduced to writing and made a part of the procurement record. 
(c)  For purposes of classification as a minority-owned business for purposes of this section, the city shall allow certification through the Virginia Department of Small Business and Supplier Diversity or certification through the city's SWaM Business Office. 
(d)  The requirements of this section shall not apply to emergency procurements nor projects that include federal disadvantaged business enterprise requirements or similar requirements. 
(e)  The purchasing agent shall provide quarterly reports to the city council of all construction bids in excess of five million dollars ($5,000,000.00), the project goal for each solicitation, and the results of the bids for such contracts, including the proposed minority-owned business subcontracting. 
(Ord. No. 3625, § 2, 6-16-20)  
Sec. 2-224.15. - Enhanced subcontracting—Construction and goods and services contracts. 
(a)  The purchasing agent or designee, in consultation with the city's staff that have been trained to assist in the implementation of the city's SWaM program, shall review all proposed construction and goods and services solicitations to seek opportunities for enhanced subcontracting. For those selected contracts, the solicitation shall include a statement designating the contract for enhanced subcontracting and including the requirements of this section. 
(b)  A contract selected for enhanced subcontracting shall require, as a matter of responsiveness, that a bidder or offeror subcontract a minimum of fifty (50) percent, by dollar amount of the bid or proposal total. 
(c)  The review of good faith efforts described in sections 2-224.2 and 2-224.6 shall apply. All other requirements in section 2-224.3 for construction contracts and section 2-224.4 for goods and services contracts shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 3626, § 2, 6-16-20)  
DIVISION 3. - CITY TREASURER[12] 

Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
Charter reference— City treasurer, § 8.03. 
 
Sec. 2-225. - Bond. 
The city treasurer shall furnish a bond, with a surety company authorized to do business in the state, in a sum of not less than five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) or more than one million two hundred fifty thousand dollars ($1,250,000.00) for the faithful discharge, by the city treasurer, of the official duties of his office as city treasurer and such other official duties as are, or may be, imposed upon the city treasurer by law and by the Charter and the provisions of this Code and other ordinances of the city. The surety company shall be approved and be satisfactory to the city manager. The form of the bond shall be approved by the city attorney. 
(Code 1965, § 2-116) 
Charter reference— Authority to require bond, § 3.05(e).  
Sec. 2-226. - City depositories generally. 
(a)  The city treasurer is authorized to deposit or cause to be deposited all funds of the city in any of the following listed banks or savings and loan associations: 
(1)  Bank of the Commonwealth; 
(2)  First Union; 
(3)  Wachovia; 
(4)  BB&T; 
(5)  Centura; 
(6)  First Virginia Bank of Tidewater; 
(7)  Bank of America; 
(8)  Crestar Bank; 
(9)  Cenit Bank for Savings, SFB; 
(10)  Bank of Tidewater; 
(11)  Bank of Hampton Roads; 
(12)  Resource Bank; 
(13)  Community Bank; 
(14)  TowneBank. 
(b)  No money shall be deposited in any bank or savings and loan association referred to in this section until the bank or savings and loan association has complied with the Virginia Security for Public Deposits Act, as amended, and other provisions of state law. 
(Code 1965, §§ 2-121, 2-122; Ord. No. 1049, 6-16-80; Ord. No. 1439, 3-5-84; Ord. No. 1503, 12-17-84; Ord. No. 1813, 10-24-88; Ord. No. 1997, 8-7-90; Ord. No. 2259, 1-25-94; Ord. No. 2510, 10-6-98; Ord. No. 2568, 12-7-99) 
State Law reference— Virginia Security for Public Deposits Act, Code of Virginia, § 2.1-359 et seq.  
Sec. 2-227. - Safe deposit boxes for securities and other papers of various funds. 
The securities and other papers of the various funds of the city, under the control of the city treasurer, shall be deposited in safe deposit boxes in banks located in the city. The opening of such safe deposit boxes and the checking and examination of the contents thereof, shall be only upon the demand and control of, and in the presence of, the city treasurer. 
(Code 1965, §§ 2-117, 2-118)  
Sec. 2-228. - Paid and redeemed bonds—Custodian. 
The city treasurer is hereby designated the custodian of bonds and coupons comprising the bonded debt of the city, when such bonds and coupons have been paid or otherwise redeemed. 
(Code 1965, § 2-119) 
Charter reference— Issuance of bonds and notes, Ch. 6.  
Sec. 2-229. - Same—Cancellation and destruction. 
The city treasurer shall cause the paid or redeemed bonds and coupons referred to in section 2-228 to be canceled and destroyed and shall retain a permanent record of such cancellation and destruction in accordance with sound accounting practices and the laws of the state. When the paid bonds and coupons have been destroyed, a certificate of such destruction, containing an itemized list of the bonds and coupons destroyed, shall be filed with the director of finance and one such certificate shall be retained by the treasurer. 
(Code 1965, § 2-120)  
Sec. 2-230. - Treasurer authorized to impose penalty charge for bad checks. 
The city treasurer is hereby authorized and required to impose a penalty charge of thirty-five dollars ($35.00) for any bad checks submitted for payment of any taxes, levies or fees due to the city. A "bad check" is any check or draft returned for insufficient funds or because there is no account or the account has been closed. 
(Ord. No. 1321, 9-13-82; Ord. No. 1625, 10-6-86; Ord. No. 2512, 10-13-98; Ord. No. 2958, 7-11-06) 
State Law reference— Authority for section, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-29.4.  
Sec. 2-231. - Satellite offices. 
The city treasurer shall operate satellite offices in locations other than the municipal complex as designated by city council for the purpose of providing services for the convenience of citizens. 
(Ord. No. 1374, 6-6-83) 
Charter reference— Authority of city council to assign duties to treasurer not inconsistent with state law, § 8.03.  
Sec. 2-232. - Penalty and interest on past due accounts. 
(a)  Pursuant to section 15.2-105 of the Code of Virginia, as amended, any person who fails to pay the city treasurer the amount due on any city account on or before its due date shall incur a penalty thereon of ten (10) percent of the amount due or ten dollars ($10.00), whichever is greater, which shall be added to the amount of the account due from such person; provided, however, that in no case shall the penalty exceed the amount of the account that is past due. No penalty shall be imposed for failure to pay any account if such failure was not in any way the fault of the debtor. 
(b)  Interest at a rate not to exceed ten (10) percent annually from the first day following the day such account is due may be collected upon the principal and penalty of all such accounts. 
(c)  For purposes of this section, the "due date" of a city account shall mean the last day of the month immediately following the month in which the city's initial bill is mailed. 
(d)  This section shall not be applicable to taxes, or to any account the late payment of which is subject to penalty and interest pursuant to other provisions of the law. 
(Ord. No. 2353, 10-24-95; Ord. No. 3069, 3-10-09)  
Secs. 2-233, 2-234. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - PAYMENTS TO PERSONS DISPLACED BY CITY ROAD PROJECTS[13] 

Footnotes: 
--- (13) --- 
Cross reference— Streets and sidewalks, Ch. 33. 
 
Sec. 2-235. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this division, the following words and terms shall take the meanings ascribed to them in this section: 
Business means any lawful activity, excepting a farm operation, conducted primarily: 
(1)  For the purchase, sale, lease and rental of personal and real property and for the manufacture, processing or marketing of products, commodities or any other personal property. 
(2)  For the sale of services of the public. 
(3)  By a nonprofit organization. 
City agency means any department of the city. 
Displaced person means any person who, on or after July 1, 1980, moves from any real property or moves his personal property from real property, as a result of the acquisition of such real property, in whole or in part, or as a result of the written order of an acquiring city agency to vacate real property, for any road program or project undertaken by a city agency. 
Farm operation means any activity conducted solely or primarily for the production of one or more agricultural products or commodities, including timber, for sale or home use and customarily producing such products or commodities in sufficient quantity to be capable of contributing materially to the operator's support. The term "contributing materially," as used in this definition, means the farm operation must contribute at least one-third of the operator's income. 
Initiation of negotiation for a parcel means the date the city agency makes the first personal contact with the owner of a parcel or property to be acquired, or his designated representative, to give him a written offer for the property to be acquired. 
Person means any individual, partnership, corporation or association. 
(Ord. No. 1103, 10-13-80)  
Sec. 2-236. - Purpose of and necessity for division. 
(a)  This division is enacted to establish a uniform policy for treatment of persons displaced as a result of road programs or projects involving the acquisition of real property therefor. 
(b)  In order to acquire the rights-of-way necessary for the construction, reconstruction, maintenance and repair of the public roads of the city, it often becomes necessary for individuals, businesses, farms and nonprofit organizations to be displaced. To insure to the maximum extent possible the equitable treatment of these displacees, it is necessary for a uniform policy to be established for making moving cost payments, replacement housing cost payments and other expense payments, so that these individuals will not suffer disproportionate injuries as a result of the road improvement programs which are necessary or desirable to secure and promote the general welfare of the inhabitants of the city. 
(c)  The main objective of this division is to provide payments to be made to those who are required to relocate, in whole or in part, for costs incurred for moving, replacement housing and certain other expenses because of city road programs and projects. 
(Ord. No. 1103, 10-13-80)  
Sec. 2-237. - Applicability of division. 
(a)  The provisions of this division are applicable to any person who is displaced by any city road project on which state or federal funds are not used or for which state or federal funds do not become available before or after the city road project is approved and funded. 
(b)  This division shall not apply to acquisitions by a city agency which are voluntarily initiated or negotiated by the seller under no threat of condemnation, where property is dedicated pursuant to the provisions of chapter 11 (section 15.2-2200 et seq.) of title 15.2 of the Code of Virginia, or where property is voluntarily dedicated or donated for no consideration; provided, however, that the provisions of this division relating to relocation payments shall apply for the benefit of persons, other than the owner, who are actually and lawfully occupying the real property to be acquired and who have been occupants thereof for at least ninety (90) days prior to the initiation of negotiations for acquisition. 
(Ord. No. 1103, 10-13-80; Ord. No. 3069, 3-10-09)  
Sec. 2-238. - Funds for carrying out provisions of division. 
Funds appropriated or otherwise available to any city agency for the acquisition of real property or any interest therein for a road program or project shall be available also for obligation add expenditure to carry out the provisions of this division, as applied to that program or project. 
(Ord. No. 1103, 10-13-80)  
Sec. 2-239. - Payments for moving expenses. 
Whenever the acquisition of real property for a road program or project by a city agency will result in the displacement of any person, such agency shall make fair and equitable relocation payments to such displaced person for actual, reasonable expenses in moving himself, his family, business, farm operation or other personal property. Such payment shall not exceed two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00). 
(Ord. No. 1103, 10-13-80; Ord. No. 1942, 2-5-90)  
Sec. 2-240. - Payment for loss of earnings from business or farm operation. 
(a)  Any displaced person eligible for payments under section 2-239 who is displaced from his place of business or from his farm operation, and who elects to accept the payment authorized by this section, in lieu of the payment authorized by section 2-239, may receive a fixed payment in the amount equal to the average annual net earnings of the business or farm operation; provided that, such payment shall not be less than two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) nor more than twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00). 
(b)  In the case of a business, no payment shall be made under this section, unless the city agency is satisfied that the business: 
(1)  Cannot be relocated without a substantial loss of its existing patronage; and 
(2)  Is not a part of a commercial enterprise having at least one other establishment not being acquired by the city agency, which is engaged in the same or similar business. 
(c)  For the purpose of this section, the term "average net earnings" means one-half of any net earnings of the business or farm operation, before federal and state income taxes, during the two (2) taxable years immediately preceding the taxable year in which such business or farm operation moves from the real property acquired for such project, or during such other period as such agency determines to be more equitable for establishing such earnings, including any compensation paid by the business or farm operation to the owner, his spouse or his dependents during such period. 
(Ord. No. 1103, 10-13-80; Ord. No. 1942, 2-5-90)  
Sec. 2-241. - Payment for purchase of replacement dwelling. 
(a)  In addition to payments otherwise authorized by this division, the city agency shall make additional payments, not in excess of twenty-two thousand five hundred dollars ($22,500.00) to any displaced person who is displaced from a dwelling actually owned and occupied by such displaced person for not less than one hundred eighty (180) days prior to the initiation of negotiations for the acquisition of the property. Such additional payment shall include the following elements: 
(1)  The amount, if any, which when added to the acquisition cost of the dwelling acquired, equals the reasonable cost of a comparable replacement dwelling. 
(2)  Reasonable expenses incurred by such displaced person for evidence of title, recording fees and other closing costs incident to the purchase of the replacement dwelling, but not including prepaid expenses. 
(b)  The additional payment authorized by this section shall be made only to such displayed person who purchases and occupies a replacement dwelling not later than the end of the one-year period beginning on the date on which he receives final payment of all costs of the acquired dwelling, or on the date on which he moves from the acquired dwelling, whichever is the later date. 
(Ord. No. 1103, 10-13-80; Ord. No. 1942, 2-5-90)  
Sec. 2-242. - Payment for lease or rental of dwelling by persons not eligible for payment under section 2-241. 
In addition to amounts otherwise authorized by this division a city agency shall make payment to or for any displaced person who is not eligible to receive payment under section 2-241, but who is displaced from any dwelling that was actually and lawfully occupied by such displaced person not less than ninety (90) days prior to initiations for acquisition of such dwelling. Such payment shall be the amount necessary to enable such displaced person to lease or rent, for a period not to exceed one year, a dwelling adequate to accommodate such person, but not to exceed five thousand two hundred fifty dollars ($5,250.00). 
(Ord. No. 1103, 10-13-80; Ord. No. 1942, 2-5-90)  
Secs. 2-243—2-245. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - DEPARTMENT OF BUDGET AND MANAGEMENT SERVICES[14] 

Footnotes: 
--- (14) --- 
Editor's note— Prior to its repeal and reenactment by Ord. No. 2129, adopted May 12, 1992, this article related to the department of permits and inspections, consisted of §§ 2-246—2-251, and was derived from Code 1965, §§ 2-71, 2-72, and Ord. Nos. 1640, 1920, and 1955. Subsequently, Ord. No. 2272, adopted May 14, 2013, effective July 1, 2013, amended the title of Art. VII to read as herein set out. Formerly sai article was entitled Department of Management Services. 
 
Sec. 2-246. - Created; composition. 
There is hereby created a department to be designated the department of budget and management services, which shall consist of a director of the department, and such other employees as may be prescribed by the Charter, or by ordinance, or by the city manager or the director consistent therewith. 
(Ord. No. 2129, 5-12-92; Ord. No. 2326, 5-9-95; Ord. No. 3272, 5-14-13, eff. 7-1-13) 
Charter reference— Authority of council to create departments, §§ 3.05(b), 7.01.  
Sec. 2-247. - Functions. 
The department of budget and management services shall be responsible for resource management, review and allocation, for budget and capital program policy development, and for the following general duties, including any other duties which may be required, assigned, or prescribed by the council or the city manager: 
(1)  Plan, prepare, and develop the annual operating budget, including estimates of appropriations and revenues for support of the operating budget, consistent with the provisions of chapter 5 of the Charter, and carry out the same duties for all amendments thereto. 
(2)  Plan, prepare, and develop the capital improvements program and capital budget in accordance with section 2-195 and carry out the same duties for all amendments thereto. 
(3)  Be responsible for short-term and multi-year financial forecasts of both expenditures and revenues and annually prepare a five-year forecast of expenditures and revenues. 
(4)  Be responsible for economic and fiscal impact analysis, policy and fiscal analysis, and program evaluation services regarding city programs, agencies, business processes and projects, and for provision of management assistance services to teams, agencies and programs to improve cost management, business processes and operations. 
(5)  Coordinate or carry out city-wide surveys, strategic and fiscal planning, and provide staff support for special studies and projects. 
(6)  Reserved. 
(Ord. No. 2129, 5-12-92; Ord. No. 2326, 5-9-95; Ord. No. 2824, 5-25-04; Ord. No. 3256, 8-14-12; Ord. No. 3272, 5-14-13, eff. 7-1-13)  
Secs. 2-248—2-265. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VIII. - DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC WORKS 
 
Sec. 2-266. - Created; general duties of director. 
A department of public works is hereby created, the head of which shall be the director of public works, whose duties shall be such as are prescribed by the Charter or ordinance or by order of the city manager. 
(Code 1965, § 2-85) 
Charter reference— Authority of council to create departments, §§ 3.05(b), 7.01.  
Sec. 2-267. - Divisions established. 
There shall be, within the department of public works, the following divisions: 
(1)  Engineering division. 
(2)  Highway division. 
(3)  Waste management division. 
(4)  Office of real estate. 
(5)  Building maintenance division. 
(6)  Automotive services division. 
(Code 1965, § 2-85.1; Ord. No. 1199, 7-6-81; Ord. No. 2129, 5-12-92; Ord. No. 2159, 6-23-92; Ord. No. 2401, 6-25-96; Ord. No. 2533, 5-11-99; Ord. No. 2824, 5-25-04)  
Sec. 2-268. - Composition, functions, etc., of engineering division. 
(a)  The engineering division of the department of public works, subject to the supervision and control of the director of public works, shall be headed by the city engineer, who shall be a civil engineer, shall have a thorough knowledge of municipal engineering and shall be charged with maintaining official technical records of all streets, highways and other public properties; providing engineering plans, drawings, specifications and supervision for all construction and maintenance work where required; providing or reviewing all technical information for contracts submitted for public works operations or construction; and providing engineering services and supervision to the city as may be prescribed. 
(b)  The city surveyor shall serve within the engineering division of the department of public works and shall be subject to the supervision and control of the city engineer, and shall be charged with the ascertainment, fixing and marking of lines of streets, alleys and the boundaries of lots, the regulation of party walls and partition fences and matters related thereto and such other duties as may be required, assigned or prescribed. 
(c)  Police powers are hereby conferred upon the city engineer or designated deputies, assistants or inspectors while engaged in performing their duties, and they are each hereby granted the authority to issue stop-work orders, to serve written notices of violation, to order the abatement of such violation and to issue a summons to the general district court to any person in the city who shall fail to obey a lawful order contained in such stop-work order or notice of violation. 
(Code 1965, § 2-85.1; Ord. No. 2401, 6-25-96; Ord. No. 3182, 5-24-11)  
Sec. 2-269. - Composition and duties of highway division. 
The highway division of the department of public works, subject to the supervision and control of the director of public works, shall be headed by the highway engineer, who shall be charged with responsibility for the construction, improvement, repair and use of streets, alleys, lanes, bridges, viaducts and other public highways, and matters relating thereto and such other duties as may be required or prescribed. 
(Code 1965, § 2-85.1) 
Cross reference— Streets, Ch. 33.  
Sec. 2-270. - Composition, powers and duties of solid waste division. 
(a)  The solid waste division of the department of public works, subject to the supervision and control of the director of public works, shall be headed by the solid waste administrator, who shall be charged with responsibility for the cleaning of streets and public places, including beaches, and the collection and disposal of garbage and waste, public and private conformance with the sanitation regulations of the city and such other duties as may be required, assigned or prescribed. 
(b)  Police powers are hereby conferred upon the solid waste administrator, or designated deputies or assistants while engaged in the performance of their duties, and they shall exercise all powers and authority of police officers in performing such duties. The names of the deputies or assistants so designated shall be submitted to the city manager for approval. 
(Code 1965, § 2-85.1; Ord. No. 1200, 7-6-81) 
Cross reference— Solid waste, Ch. 31.  
Sec. 2-271. - Composition and duties of traffic division. 
The traffic division of the department of public works, subject to the supervision of the director of public works, shall be headed by the traffic engineer, who shall be charged with responsibility for the movement of traffic on the city streets and such other duties as may be required, assigned or prescribed. 
(Code 1965, § 2-85.1) 
Cross reference— Traffic, Ch. 21.  
Sec. 2-272. - Composition and duties of office of real estate. 
The office of real estate, within the department of public works, subject to the supervision and control of the director of public works, shall be headed by the real estate agent, who shall be responsible for all matters related to such office and which may be required, assigned or prescribed. 
(Code 1965, § 2-85.1)  
Sec. 2-273. - Composition and duties of building maintenance division. 
The building maintenance division of the department of public works, subject to the supervision and control of the director of public works, shall be responsible for the maintenance of the buildings within the city government and matters relating thereto and such other duties as may be required or prescribed. 
(Ord. No. 2824, 5-25-04) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2401, adopted June 25, 1996, repealed §§ 2-273 and 2-274, which provided for the composition of the permits and inspections division and the police powers of building official and deputies; and the composition of weights and measures division, its function, and police powers, and which derived from Ord. No. 2129, adopted May 12, 1992. Ord. No. 2824, adopted May 25, 2004, added new provisions to the Code as § 2-273 as herein set out.  
Sec. 2-274. - Reserved. 
Note— See the editor's note following § 2-273.  
Sec. 2-275. - Issuance of stop-work orders. 
(a)  Upon notice from the director of public works, any division head subject to the supervision and control of the director of public works or any of their designated deputies, assistants or inspectors that work is being performed contrary to the provisions of this Code, such work shall be immediately stopped. The stop-work order shall be in writing and shall be given to the owner of the property involved, or to the owner's agent, or to the person doing the work, and shall state specific violation or violations for which the order was issued and the conditions under which work may be resumed. 
(b)  Any person who shall continue any work or have his agent continue any work in or about the site after a stop-work order has been issued, except such work as he is directed to perform by the city official issuing the stop-work order to correct a violation or unsafe condition, shall be guilty of a Class 1 misdemeanor. 
(c)  Any person who is performing work in accordance with a land disturbance permit and who shall continue to have his agent continue to work in or about the site after a stop-work order has been issued, except such work as he is directed to perform by the city official issuing the stop-work order to correct a violation or unsafe condition, shall be subject to a civil penalty ordered by the Circuit Court not to exceed thirty-two thousand five hundred dollars ($32,500.00) for each violation. Each day of violation of each requirement shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1965, § 2-85.2; Ord. No. 2129, 5-12-92; Ord. No. 2401, 6-25-96; Ord. No. 3338, 4-22-14) 
Note— Formerly, § 2-273.  
Secs. 2-276—2-284. - Reserved.

ARTICLE IX. - DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC UTILITIES 
 
Sec. 2-286. - Created. 
There is hereby created a department of public utilities in and for the city. 
(Code 1965, § 2-142) 
Charter reference— Authority of council to create departments, §§ 3.05(b), 7.01.  
Sec. 2-287. - Composition. 
The department of public utilities shall consist of the director of public utilities and such officers, engineers and employees in such bureaus, divisions and other units as may be provided by this Code or other ordinances of the city or the orders of the director of public utilities consistent therewith. 
(Code 1965, § 2-142)  
Sec. 2-288. - Issuance of stop-work orders. 
(a)  Upon notice from the director of public utilities or his designees that work is being performed contrary to the provisions of any code, regulation or standard applicable to the performance of such work, such work shall be immediately stopped. The stopwork order shall be in writing and shall be given to the owner of the property involved or his agent, or to the person doing the work, and shall state the conditions under which work may be resumed. 
(b)  Any person who shall continue or allow to be continued any work in or about the site after a stop-work order has been issued shall be guilty of a Class 1 misdemeanor, unless such work is at the direction of the city official issuing the stop-work order and is performed to correct a violation or unsafe condition. 
(c)  Any person who is performing work in accordance with a land disturbance permit and who shall continue to have his agent continue to work in or about the site after a stop-work order has been issued, except such work as he is directed to perform by the city official issuing the stop-work order to correct a violation or unsafe condition, shall be subject to a civil penalty ordered by the Circuit Court not to exceed thirty-two thousand five hundred dollars ($32,500.00) for each violation. Each day of violation of each requirement shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 1250, 1-25-82; Ord. No. 3338, 4-22-14)  
Secs. 2-289—2-300. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE X. - DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH[16]

Sec. 2-301. - Created; composition. 
There is hereby created a department of public health, which shall consist of the director of public health, and such other officers and employees as may be provided by the council or by the orders of the city manager or the director consistent therewith. 
(Code 1965, § 2-128) 
Charter reference— Department of public health created, § 7.01; composition of department, § 13.01.  
Sec. 2-302. - Functions. 
The department of public health shall be responsible for the exercise of all health functions imposed on municipalities by general law and shall have such other powers and duties as may be assigned by the council. 
(Code 1965, § 2-128.1) 
Charter reference— Similar provisions, § 13.02.  
Sec. 2-303. - Qualifications and general powers and duties of director. 
The head of the department of public health shall be the director of public health. He shall be a physician licensed to practice medicine in the state. He shall have general management and control of the several bureaus, divisions and other units of the department. He shall have all the powers and duties, with respect to the preservation of the public health, which are conferred or imposed on municipal boards of health and health officers by the laws of the state. 
(Code 1965, § 2-128.2) 
Charter reference— Similar provisions, § 13.03.  
Sec. 2-304. - Police powers of personnel. 
The director of public health, the sanitarian supervisors and the sanitarian aide for rabies control of the department of public health are hereby vested with such powers as have the police officers of the city. 
(Code 1965, § 2-128.3)

ARTICLE XI. - DEPARTMENT OF HUMAN SERVICES[17] 

Footnotes: 
--- (17) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2854, adopted Dec. 7, 2004, amended Art. XI of this chapter in its entirety to read as herein set out. Prior to amendment, Art. XI, §§ 2-316—2-318, of this chapter pertained to the department of mental health, mental retardation and substance abuse services and derived from the 1965 Code, §§ 2-150—2-152; and Ord. No. 2498, adopted July 7, 1998. 
State Law reference— Community mental health and mental retardation services, Code of Virginia, § 37.1-194 et seq. 
 
Sec. 2-316. - Created; composition. 
There is hereby created a department of human services, which shall consist of a director and such other officers and employees as may be provided by the council or by the orders of the city manager or director consistent therewith. 
(Ord. No. 2854, 12-7-04) 
Charter reference— Authority of council to create departments, §§ 3.05(b), 7.01.  
Sec. 2-317. - Appointment, powers and duties of director. 
The director of the department of human services shall be the executive director of the community services board, who shall be appointed in accordance with section 37.1-197(B)(6) of the Code of Virginia. The director shall have general management and control of the several divisions, bureaus and other units of the department, including the juvenile detention center, and shall have all the powers and duties that are conferred by the community services board. 
(Ord. No. 2854, 12-7-04)  
Sec. 2-318. - Establishment and responsibilities of division of social services. 
There is hereby established, within the department of human services, the division of social services, which shall consist of such officers and employees as may be provided by ordinance or by orders or directives consistent therewith. This division shall be responsible for the exercise of all social services functions imposed on municipalities by general law. 
(Ord. No. 2854, 12-7-04)  
Sec. 2-319. - Establishment and responsibilities of division of behavioral health and developmental services. 
There is hereby established, within the department of human services, the division of behavioral health and developmental services, which shall consist of such officers and employees as may be provided by ordinance or by orders or directives consistent therewith. This division shall be responsible for the exercise of all behavioral health, developmental and substance abuse services functions imposed on municipalities by general law and provide such services in coordination with the advice from the community services board. 
(Ord. No. 2854, 12-7-04; Ord. No. 3488, 2-21-17)  
Sec. 2-320. - Designation and duties of local board of public welfare. 
Pursuant to section 63.2-304 of the Code of Virginia, the director of human services is hereby designated as and shall constitute the local board of public welfare. The director shall discharge the duties and functions of such boards as imposed by title 63.2 of the Code of Virginia. 
(Ord. No. 2854, 12-7-04)  
Sec. 2-321. - Creation of social services advisory board; general function; powers and duties. 
(a)  There is hereby created a social services advisory board for the city, which shall consist of nine (9) members appointed by the city council. The director of human services shall be an ex officio member, without any voting privileges. 
(b)  The board shall act in an advisory capacity to the director of human services with respect to the duties and functions imposed by title 63.2 of the Code of Virginia. 
(c)  The powers and duties of the board shall be as enumerated in section 63.2-305 of the Code of Virginia. 
(d)  As required by section 63.2-305 of the Code of Virginia, and notwithstanding the provisions of City Code section 2-3(b), no voting member shall serve more than two (2) consecutive four-year terms. 
(Ord. No. 2854, 12-7-04; Ord. No. 3075, 4-14-09; Ord. No. 3296, 6-25-13)  
Secs. 2-322—2-330. - Reserved.

ARTICLE XIII.5. - PUBLIC RECORDS MANAGEMENT[20] 

Footnotes: 
--- (20) --- 
Cross reference— Concealing, destroying, etc., city records, § 23-42. 
State Law reference— Virginia Public Records Act, Code of Virginia, § 42.1-76 et seq. 
 
Sec. 2-341. - Definition. 
As used in this article, "city records" shall mean all written books, papers, letters, documents, photographs, tapes, microfiche, microfilm, photostats, sound recordings, maps, other documentary materials or information in any recording medium, regardless of physical form or characteristics, including data processing devices and computers, made or received in pursuance of law or in connection with the transaction of public business by any office or department of the government of the City of Virginia Beach. "City records" shall not be deemed to include any such items made or received by individual members of the city council. 
Nonrecord materials, which shall include reference books and exhibit materials made or acquired and preserved solely for reference use or exhibition purposes, extra copies of documents preserved only for convenience or reference, and stocks of publications, shall not be included within the definition of "city records" as used in this article. 
(Ord. No. 1818, 11-21-88)  
Sec. 2-342. - City records declared public property. 
(a)  All city records shall be, and are hereby declared to be, the property of the City of Virginia Beach. No city officer or employee shall have, by virtue of his position as an officer or employee of the city, any personal or property right in or to any such records. 
(b)  Any custodian of any city record or records shall, upon the expiration of his tenure of office, appointment or employment, deliver to his successor, or if there be none, to the city records manager, all books, writings, letters, documents and other city records and information in his custody. 
(Ord. No. 1818, 11-21-88)  
Sec. 2-343. - Custody and preservation of records of the city council. 
(a)  The city clerk shall retain the records of the city council. 
(b)  The city clerk shall retain an original of the minutes of the meetings of the city council. In addition, a copy of such minutes shall be scanned and stored in an optical image database. 
(Ord. No. 1818, 11-21-88; Ord. No. 2332, 6-6-95)  
Sec. 2-344. - Records management program established. 
It shall be the duty of the city manager to develop a comprehensive program for the management of city records, including the establishment of procedures for the management of such records from their creation to their ultimate disposition and for the efficient and economical creation, distribution, maintenance, use, preservation and disposition of city records. 
(Ord. No. 1818, 11-21-88)  
Sec. 2-345. - Records manager; duties. 
The public records coordinator is hereby designated as records manager, who shall be responsible for the implementation of the records management program. 
(Ord. No. 1818, 11-21-88; Ord. No. 3326, 2-11-14)  
Sec. 2-346. - Duties of department heads; records officers. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the department directors to cooperate with the city manager in implementing the records management program; provided, that nothing in this article shall be construed to require the removal of city records from the custody of a department director when such records are deemed necessary in or for the performance of the duties imposed upon such director by statute or ordinance. 
(b)  Each department director shall designate an employee of his department to act as records representative, who shall report directly to the director of his department and shall be responsible for coordinating the records management program of his department, for cooperating with the records manager in ensuring compliance with the records management program, and for monitoring compliance with records retention and disposition schedules for the records of his department. 
(Ord. No. 1818, 11-21-88; Ord. No. 3326, 2-11-14)  
Sec. 2-347. - Confidentiality. 
Any records made confidential by law shall be so treated. Records which by law are required to be closed to the public shall not be deemed to be made open to the public under the provisions of this article, and no provision of this article shall be construed to authorize or require the opening of any records ordered by a court to be sealed. 
(Ord. No. 1818, 11-21-88)  
Sec. 2-347.1. - Records retention. 
In accordance with the Code of Virginia § 58.1-3129 (A), the city treasurer may destroy all paid personal property tax tickets at any time after five (5) years from the end of the fiscal year during which taxes represented by such tickets were paid, provided that such destruction shall be in accordance with the provisions of the Virginia Public Records Act. 
(Ord. No. 3066, 2-24-09)
