ARTICLE XV. - DEPARTMENT OF ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT[22] 

Footnotes: 
--- (22) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1776, adopted May 9, 1988, amended Art. XV by amending § 2-363, repealing §§ 2-364—2-366 and 2-369, and renumbering §§ 2-367 and 2-368 as §§ 2-364 and 2-365. Said repealed sections pertained to the duties of the tourist development division, the industrial development division and the convention promotion division, and the citizens advisory committee, and were derived from Code 1965, §§ 2-134, 2-135, 2-137; and Ord. No. 958, adopted July 2, 1979. 
 
Sec. 2-361. - Created.

Charter reference— Authority of council to create departments, §§ 3.05(b), 7.01.  
Sec. 2-362. - Office of director created; general duties of director. 
There shall be a director of economic development, who shall be the head of the department of economic development and whose duties shall be such as may be prescribed by the Charter or ordinance or by order of the city manager. 
(Code 1965, § 2-133)  
Sec. 2-363. - General duties of the department of economic development. 
The department of economic development shall be responsible for the following general duties, including any other duties which may be required, assigned, or prescribed: 
(1)  Business retention and expansion on a city wide basis, including, but not limited to, industrial and commercial solicitations and locations, development and coordination of advertising programs, coordination and development of industrial parks and facilities in conjunction with the Virginia Beach Development Authority, and promotion of port, inlet, and airport facilities; 
(2)  Agricultural economic coordination, including, but not limited to, liaison duties between the departments of economic development and agriculture to ensure and improve agriculture's posture in the city's economic mix. 
(Code 1965, § 2-134; Ord. No. 958, 7-2-79; Ord. No. 1776, 5-9-88; Ord. No. 1792, 7-11-88)  
Sec. 2-364. - Assistance to development authority. 
The director of economic development and his staff shall provide assistance to the development authority in its business development activities. 
(Code 1965, § 2-135; Ord. No. 9358, 7-2-79; Ord. No. 1776, 5-9-88)  
Sec. 2-365. - Advertising program. 
The department of economic development, under the direction of the city manager and the director of economic development, with necessary staff assistance, shall develop an advertising program and shall have authority to expend, for advertising and publicizing the city and its resources and facilities, such funds as the city may appropriate for this purpose and to receive and expend for advertising purposes, any funds received from other organizations for such advertising purposes. 
(Code 1965, § 2-136; Ord. No. 1776, 5-9-88) 
Charter reference— Authority of city to make expenditures for advertising its resources and advantages, § 2.02.

ARTICLE XVI. - DEPARTMENT OF PLANNING 
 
Sec. 2-381. - Created. 
There is hereby created a department of planning in and for the city. 
(Code 1965, § 2-131) 
Charter reference— Authority of council to create departments, §§ 3.05(b), 7.01.  
Sec. 2-382. - Composition. 
The department of planning shall consist of a director appointed by the city manager and such assistants as may be provided. The department of planning shall also include a permits and inspections division and a zoning administrator, who shall possess all powers and authority granted to such officers by statute, ordinance or charter. 
(Ord. No. 2401, 6-25-96; Ord. No. 2994, 7-10-07) 
Cross reference— Zoning, App. A.  
Sec. 2-383. - General duties. 
The department of planning shall assist the planning commission in the performance of its duties and shall perform such other tasks as may be assigned by the city council or by the city manager. 
(Code 1965, § 2-131)  
Sec. 2-384. - Duties of director with respect to street names. 
It is the responsibility of the director of planning to review the names of proposed new streets to ensure that no conflict exists with existing or previously approved street names. The names of existing streets shall be as they have been or from time to time may be changed by the director of planning after notice has been given to the adjacent property owners. Appeals shall be directed to the city council within thirty (30) days from the date of notification. 
(Code 1965, § 2-132) 
Cross reference— Streets and sidewalks, Ch. 33.  
Sec. 2-385. - Duties and powers of zoning administrator. 
The zoning administrator and his designated deputies and assistants shall be responsible for the enforcement of all zoning ordinances of the city. Police powers are hereby conferred upon the zoning administrator and his designated deputies and assistants while engaged in performing their duties, and they shall exercise all powers and authority of police officers in performing such duties. 
(Ord. No. 2129, 5-12-92) 
Cross reference— Zoning, App. A.  
Sec. 2-386. - Composition of permits and inspections division; police powers of building official, deputies and division inspectors. 
(a)  The permits and inspections division of the department of planning shall be responsible for all matters pertaining to, and the enforcement of, the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code ("USBC") and all model building codes which have been adopted and incorporated by reference into the Code of the City of Virginia Beach under article II of chapter 8 hereof, fire and health inspections for new construction, including the ordering, in writing, of the remedying of any condition found in violation of such codes or any ordinance, and the bringing of legal action to ensure compliance therewith, including injunction, abatement and any other appropriate action or proceedings. Such division shall perform such other duties as may be required, assigned or prescribed. 
(b)  There shall be, within the permits and inspections division, a building code administrator who shall perform all of the functions and have all of the powers of the code official as set forth in the USBC for new construction. Police powers are hereby conferred upon the building code administrator and designated deputies or inspectors assigned to the permits and inspections division while engaged in performing their duties, and they are each hereby granted the authority to issue stop-work orders, to serve written notices of violation, to order the abatement of such violation and to issue a summons to the general district court to any person in the city who shall fail to obey a lawful order contained in such stop-work order or notice of violation. 
(Ord. No. 2401, 6-25-96; Ord. No. 2470, 2-10-98)  
Sec. 2-387. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 2994, adopted July 10, 2007, repealed § 2-387, which pertained to composition of weights and measures bureau, function; police powers and derived from Ord. No. 2401, 6-25-96.  
Sec. 2-388. - Issuance of stop-work orders. 
(a)  Upon notice from the director of planning, any division head subject to the supervision and control of the director of planning or any of their designated deputies, assistants or inspectors that work is being performed contrary to the provisions of this Code, such work shall be immediately stopped. The stop-work order shall be in writing and shall be given to the owner of the property involved, or to the owner's agent, or to the person doing the work, and shall state specific violation or violations for which the order was issued and the conditions under which work may be resumed. 
(b)  Any person who shall continue any work or have his agent continue any work in or about the site after a stop-work order has been issued, except such work as he is directed to perform by the city official issuing the stop-work order to correct a violation or unsafe condition, shall be guilty of a Class 1 misdemeanor. 
(c)  Any person who is performing work in accordance with a land disturbance permit and who shall continue to have his agent continue to work in or about the site after a stop-work order has been issued, except such work as he is directed to perform by the city official issuing the stop-work order to correct a violation or unsafe condition, shall be subject to a civil penalty ordered by the Circuit Court not to exceed thirty-two thousand five hundred dollars ($32,500.00) for each violation. Each day of violation of each requirement shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 2401, 6-25-96; Ord. No. 3338, 4-22-14)  
Secs. 2-389—2-395. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XVII. - PLANNING COMMISSION[23] 

Footnotes: 
--- (23) --- 
Charter reference— Planning commission, §§ 19.01, 19.02. 
Cross reference— Planning commission action on application for sign permit, § 3-25. 
State Law reference— Local planning commissions, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-427.1 et seq. 
 
Sec. 2-396. - Composition; organization; appointment and qualifications of members. 
The planning commission of the city shall consist of eleven (11) members. One member shall be appointed from among the residents of each of the seven (7) residence districts of the city, and the four (4) additional members shall be appointed from the city at large; provided, however, that at least one (1) of the at-large members shall be appointed from among the residents of the former Pungo or Blackwater Borough. The commission shall be organized as provided by general law. All members of the commission shall be appointed by the council and shall be residents of the city, qualified by knowledge and experience to make decisions on questions on community growth and development; provided that at least six (6) of the members so appointed shall be owners of real property located in the city. 
(Code 1965, § 2-129; Ord. No. 1544, 7-1-85; Ord. No. 2464, 12-16-97) 
Charter reference— Planning commission created, § 19.01. 
State Law reference— Duty to create local planning commission, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-427.1; provisions similar to above section, § 15.1-437.  
Sec. 2-397. - Terms of members. 
Members of the planning commission shall be appointed for terms of four (4) years. 
(Code 1965, § 2-129) 
Cross reference— Limitation on terms of members of boards and commissions and application for appointment of such members, § 2-3. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-437.  
Sec. 2-398. - Removal of members. 
In addition to the grounds for removal from office of any member of the planning commission set forth in section 15.2-2212 of the Code of Virginia, a failure to attend three (3) consecutive meetings, called or regular, of the planning commission shall constitute cause for removal. 
(Code 1965, § 2-130; Ord. No. 2558, 8-10-99)  
Secs. 2-399—2-410. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XVIII. - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT OFFICE[24] 

Footnotes: 
--- (24) --- 
State Law reference— Virginia Emergency Services and Disaster Law, Code of Virginia, § 44-146.13 et seq. 
 
Sec. 2-411. - Created; director; coordinator. 
In accordance with section 44-146.19 of the Code of Virginia, an office of emergency management is hereby created for and within the city. The city manager is hereby appointed as director of emergency management. A coordinator shall be appointed by the director, with the consent of council. The Deputy City Manager for Public Safety shall be the coordinator of emergency management. 
(Code 1965, § 2-139; Ord. No. 1702, 6-1-87; Ord. No. 3481, 12-13-16) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 44-146.19.  
Sec. 2-412. - General powers and duties of director. 
(a)  In collaboration with other public and private agencies within the state, the director of emergency management shall develop or cause to be developed mutual aid arrangements for reciprocal assistance in case of a disaster too great to be dealt with unassisted. 
(b)  The director of emergency management shall prepare and keep current a local or interjurisdictional emergency plan for the area. This shall include, but not be limited to, responsibilities of all local agencies and shall establish a chain of command. 
(Code 1965, § 2-140; Ord. No. 1702, 6-1-87) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 44-146.19.  
Sec. 2-413. - Declaration of emergencies. 
A local emergency may be declared by the director of emergency management, with the consent of the council. In the event the council cannot convene due to the disaster, the director or any member of the council, in the absence of the director, may declare the existence of a local disaster subject to confirmation by the council at its next regularly scheduled meeting or at a special meeting within 45 days of the declaration, whichever occurs first. The council, when in its judgment all emergency actions have been taken, shall take appropriate action to end the declared emergency. 
(Code 1965, § 2-141; Ord. No. 1702, 6-1-87; Ord. No. 2981, 6-5-07; Ord. No. 3457, 8-2-16) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 44-146.21.  
Secs. 2-414—2-420. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XIX. - DEPARTMENT OF EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICES[25] 

Footnotes: 
--- (25) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1160, enacted April 13, 1981, amended the 1965 Code by adding Art. XXV, §§ 2-153—2-155; the editor has redesignated these provisions as Art. XIX, §§ 2-421—2-423. 
Cross reference— Emergency medical care agencies and vehicles, Ch. 10.5. 
 
Sec. 2-421. - Creation; composition. 
There is hereby created a department of emergency medical services, which shall consist of an emergency medical services chief, a medical director endorsed by the Virginia Beach Medical Society, the members of the operational volunteer rescue squads serving the city and such other committees, boards, organizations and personnel as may be ordered by the city manager, the medical director or the chief consistent herewith. Such members, committees, boards, organizations and personnel shall be under the supervision and control of the emergency medical services chief. Personnel assigned to the fire department shall be under the supervision and control of the emergency medical services chief and the fire chief whenever they are engaged in emergency medical services and rescue services activities as defined in section 2-422. The emergency medical services chief and medical director shall be appointed by the city manager. The medical director shall be appointed for a term of two (2) years and shall be eligible for reappointment. 
(Ord. No. 1160, 4-13-81; Ord. No. 1470, 7-9-84; Ord. No. 1956, 5-7-90; Ord. No. 2404, 7-2-96; Ord. No. 3433, 12-1-15) 
Cross reference— Volunteer rescue squads listed, § 2-4.  
Sec. 2-422. - Functions. 
The department of emergency medical services shall be responsible for controlling and supervising the provision of emergency medical services and rescue services in the city to protect and promote the health, welfare and safety of the general public. Such services shall include, but not be limited to: basic and advanced life support patient care; preventative care; patient care at accidents of any nature involving injuries and/or illnesses; mass casualty incidents; water rescues, including, boat, lifeguard and rescue dive operations services; and all other incidents involving injured or ill patients. Such services shall not include (i) rescues which involve an imminent danger or the actual occurrence of fire or explosion, or the uncontrolled release of hazardous materials which threaten life, or (ii) search and rescue operations conducted by law enforcement officers. The department shall be responsible for establishing and enforcing applicable rules, regulations, policies and protocols for the department and for other city agencies and the agencies which are defined under chapter 10.5 of the Code. The department shall have other such powers and duties as may be assigned by council or the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 1160, 4-13-81; Ord. No. 1470, 7-9-84; Ord. No. 1956, 5-7-90; Ord. No. 2404, 7-2-96; Ord. No. 3433, 12-1-15)  
Sec. 2-423. - General powers and duties of director and chief. 
(a)  The medical director shall be responsible for the establishment of medical policy dealing with the direction and coordination of patient care operations for the department, including, but not limited to, the granting of the authorization to practice to EMS personnel as defined in the Code of Virginia, § 54.1-3408, the development of medical training standards, medical care procedures and protocols, medical performance standards and general medical control. 
(b)  The emergency medical services chief shall make rules, regulations and policies concerning the general management, direction, operation and control of the department of emergency medical services, as well as the provision of emergency medical services and rescue services in the city, including, but not limited to, the certification of emergency medical services personnel to operate within the city consistent with policies promulgated by the medical director; the implementation of medical and operational policy and protocol; and the supervision of all personnel within the department, as well as any other personnel involved in the provision of emergency medical and rescue services as set forth in section 2-422 of this code. 
(c)  The rules, regulations and policies of the medical director and emergency medical services chief shall be subject to approval by the city manager and shall not be inconsistent with the laws of the commonwealth. 
(Ord. No. 1160, 4-13-81; Ord. No. 1470, 7-9-84; Ord. No. 1956, 5-7-90; Ord. No. 2404, 7-2-96; Ord. No. 3433, 12-1-15)  
Sec. 2-424. - Advisory boards. 
(a)  The Council of Virginia Beach Volunteer Rescue Squads, Inc. shall serve as an advisory board to the emergency medical services chief, providing recommendations on department policy matters as necessary. The advisory board may also provide recommendations to the city manager concerning the selection of the emergency medical services chief when vacancies occur in that position, and other matters pertaining to the duties, responsibilities and functions of the department of emergency medical services. 
(b)  Additional boards which may be created shall have duties as enumerated to them by the city manager, medical director or the emergency medical services chief. 
(Ord. No. 1470, 7-9-84; Ord. No. 1956, 5-7-90; Ord. No. 2404, 7-2-96; Ord. No. 3433, 12-1-15)  
Sec. 2-425. - Background investigations of applicants for certification; false representation of certification unlawful; impersonation. 
(a)  In order to determine if any past criminal conduct or motor vehicle driving record of any applicant for certification by the emergency medical services chief would be compatible with the nature of the position under consideration, the following procedure shall be followed: 
(1)  Each such applicant shall furnish a classifiable set of fingerprints to the department of police. 
(2)  The chief of police and members of the department of police acting in his name and the emergency medical services chief or an investigator designated by the emergency medical services chief within the department of emergency medical services, are authorized to conduct a field investigation and directed to conduct criminal record checks on each such applicant. 
(3)  The chief of police or a member of the police department acting on his behalf, or an investigator designated by the emergency medical services chief within the department of emergency medical services, shall prepare a factual summary of the background investigation and criminal records check of each applicant and transmit such summary to the emergency medical services chief for the purpose of determining the fitness of the applicant. 
(4)  Background investigation and records checks include records of all arrests and dispositions as an adult. Records of arrests and dispositions, while an applicant was considered a juvenile, shall be transmitted only when authorized by a court order, court rule, court decision, federal regulation or state statute authorizing such dissemination. 
(5)  Criminal history records and information shall include arrest and disposition data on file in the national crime information center, the federal bureau of investigation, the department of defense, the department of motor vehicles, and all other federal, state and local law enforcement agencies. 
(6)  Any applicant who is denied certification on the basis of the investigation summary referred to in this section may inspect that summary for the purpose of clarifying, explaining or denying the accuracy of its contents. 
(7)  The chief of police and members of the police department shall make no other dissemination to the emergency medical services chief regarding the fitness of applicants, except in the official summary report referred to in this section. 
(8)  Use of criminal history record information disseminated to the emergency medical services chief shall be limited to the purpose for which it was given and may not be disseminated further. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully impersonate, with the intent to make another believe he is an emergency medical services provider. A first offense conviction is a Class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 1588, 2-10-86; Ord. No. 1900, 8-7-89; Ord. No. 1956, 5-7-90; Ord. No. 2231, 6-8-93; Ord. No. 2709, 6-25-02; Ord. No. 3293, 6-11-13, eff. 7-1-13; Ord. No. 3433, 12-1-15)  
Secs. 2-426—2-430. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XX. - DEPARTMENT OF HOUSING AND NEIGHBORHOOD PRESERVATION[26] 

Footnotes: 
--- (26) --- 
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 1921, adopted Oct. 2, 1989, amended Art. XX, §§ 2-431 and 2-432, to read as herein set out. Prior to amendment, Art. XX pertained to the department of housing and community development, as derived from Ord. No. 1452, §§ 1 and 2, adopted May 14, 1984. 
Cross reference— Housing and building maintenance code, Ch. 16; social services, Ch. 29; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 33; zoning, App. A. 
 
Sec. 2-431. - Creation. 
There is hereby created a department of housing and neighborhood preservation. 
(Ord. No. 1921, 10-2-89)  
Sec. 2-432. - Composition. 
The department of housing and neighborhood preservation shall consist of the director of housing and neighborhood preservation and such other employees as may be provided by the Charter or by ordinance or by direction of the city manager consistent therewith. In addition thereto, the department shall, by the code enforcement administrator, perform all of the functions and have all of the powers of the code official as set forth in the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code for existing structures. Police powers are hereby conferred upon the code enforcement administrator and his or her designated employees while engaged in the performance of their duties. 
(Ord. No. 1921, 10-2-89; Ord. No. 2467, 1-13-98)

ARTICLE XXI. - VIRGINIA BEACH CONVENTION AND VISITORS BUREAU[27] 

Footnotes: 
--- (27) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2763, adopted June 3, 2003, changed the title of Art. XXI of this chapter from the "Department of Convention and Visitor Development" to the "Virginia Beach Convention and Visitors Bureau." 
 
Sec. 2-440. - Creation. 
There is hereby created a department that shall be known as the Virginia Beach convention and visitors bureau. 
(Ord. No. 1792, 7-11-88; Ord. No. 2763, 6-3-03)  
Sec. 2-441. - Office of director created; general duties of director. 
There shall be a director of the Virginia Beach convention and visitors bureau whose duties shall be as prescribed by the Charter or ordinance or by order of the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 1792, 7-11-88; Ord. No. 2763, 6-3-03)  
Sec. 2-442. - General duties of the Virginia Beach convention and visitors bureau. 
The Virginia Beach convention and visitors bureau shall be responsible for the following general duties, including any other duties which may be required, assigned or prescribed: 
(1)  Travel and tourism, including, but not limited to, the solicitation of tourist attractions, the development of and coordination of advertising programs and solicitation of activities and events appropriate for departmental facilities. All monies received from departmental event facilities and related operations during each fiscal year shall be paid into the general fund or such other funds as determined by city council. 
(2)  Convention promotion, including, but not limited to, the solicitation of conventions and the coordination of housing of convention delegates. 
(3)  The operation, maintenance and management of departmental event facilities and public parking facilities including, but not limited to, lots, on-street parking and garages, establishing and enforcing reasonable rules and regulations for the use of such facilities, as well as revenue and cost analysis, fee standards, and concession operations. 
(Ord. No. 1792, 7-11-88; Ord. No. 2533, 5-11-99; Ord. No. 2763, 6-3-03)  
Sec. 2-443. - Advertising program. 
The Virginia Beach convention and visitors bureau shall develop an advertising program and shall have the authority to expend such funds as the city may appropriate to promote the increase of travel, tourism and conventions within the city. 
(Ord. No. 1792, 7-11-88; Ord. No. 2763, 6-3-03)  
Secs. 2-444—2-450. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XXII. - BOARDS, COMMISSIONS AND COMMITTEES[28] 

Footnotes: 
--- (28) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1796, adopted August 1, 1988, added Art. XXI, § 2-441, to Ch. 2. Inasmuch as Ord. No. 1792, adopted July 11, 1988, had previously added Art. XXI, §§ 2-440—2-443, the provisions added by Ord. No. 1796 have been redesignated Art. XXII, § 2-451, herein, at the discretion of the editor. 
 
Sec. 2-451. - Definition of boards, commissions and committees. 
Boards shall be defined as those advisory council-appointive agencies which are prescribed by the Virginia State Code as "boards," as well as locally established bodies, the duty of which pertains to or is governed by federal and state codes or local ordinances. Terms shall be specified and limited in accordance with the applicable federal or state codes or local ordinances or resolutions. Those currently established are as follows: 
Board of building code appeals 
Board of zoning appeals 
Chesapeake Bay Preservation Area Board 
Community services board 
Community policy and management team—CSA at-risk youth and families 
Development authority 
Director of the office of volunteer resources 
Eastern Virginia Medical School 
Hampton Roads Economic Development Alliance 
Health services advisory board 
Historical review board 
Housing advisory board 
Minority business council 
North Landing Scenic River Advisory Board 
Pendleton Project Management Board 
Personnel board 
The planning council 
Public library board 
Senior Services of Southeastern Virginia 
Social services board 
Southeastern Public Service Authority (SPSA) 
Southeastern Tidewater Opportunity Project, Inc. (STOP) 
Tidewater Community College Board 
Towing advisory board 
Virginia Beach Community Development Corporation 
Wetlands board 
Commissions shall be defined as those advisory council-appointive agencies which are prescribed by the Virginia State Code as "commissions," plus those locally established for a specific purpose with budgetary responsibility and a structured organization with an annual report to city council. Terms shall be specified and limited in accordance with applicable state statutes or city ordinances or resolutions. Those currently established are as follows: 
Agricultural advisory commission 
Arts and humanities commission 
Bayfront Advisory Commission 
Beaches and waterways commission 
Hampton Roads Planning District Commission - HRPDC 
Historic preservation commission 
Human rights commission 
Parks and recreation commission 
Planning commission 
Resort advisory commission 
Southeastern Virginia Planning District Commission 
Tidewater Transportation District Commission 
Tidewater Youth Services Commission 
Committees shall be defined as those short-term advisory agencies appointed by city council for specific studies with regular reporting periods to the governing body and which shall be automatically abolished when their mission is accomplished and the final report filed with the city clerk for distribution to city council. Those currently established are as follows: 
Advertising advisory selection committee 
Audit committee 
Bikeways and trails advisory committee 
Employee benefits review task force 
Military economic development advisory committee 
Oceana Land Use Conformity Committee 
Open space advisory committee 
Review and allocation committee 
(Ord. No. 1796, 8-1-88; Ord. No. 2548, 7-6-99; Ord. No. 2734, 1-14-03; Ord. No. 3106, 10-27-09; Ord. No. 3216, 2-14-12; Ord. No. 3391, 1-6-15; Ord. No. 3503, 5-16-17)  
Sec. 2-451.1. - Restrictions on post-employment activities of certain appointees. 
For one (1) year after their terms of office have ended, appointees of council who received monetary compensation for service on any agency, board, commission, authority, committee, or task force may not provide personal and substantial assistance for remuneration of any kind to any party, in connection with any proceeding, application, case, contract, or other particular matter involving the city or an agency thereof, if that matter is one in which the former appointee participated personally and substantially as a council appointee through decision, approval or recommendation. 
(Ord. No. 2779, 7-8-03)  
Sec. 2-452. - Establishment of military liaison commission. 
A military liaison commission is hereby established. The mayor, the vice-mayor and city manager shall serve for the tenure of their offices or appointments, with the mayor to chair the commission. The school superintendent and chairman of the school board shall be requested to serve for the tenure of their appointments; and, the following officers, by virtue of their command posts, comprise the military representation and that they shall be requested to serve for the tenure of their respective commands: 
Commander-in-chief, U.S. Atlantic Fleet 
Commander, U.S. Naval Air Force, Atlantic Fleet 
Commander, U.S. Naval Surface Force, Atlantic Fleet 
Commander, U.S. Submarine Force, Atlantic Fleet 
Commander, Fighter Medium Attack Airborne Early Warning Wings—Atlantic/Commander, Naval Supply Center 
Commander, Fifth Coast Guard District. 
Commander, U.S. Naval Base (Norfolk) 
Deputy commander, U.S. Naval Base (Norfolk) 
Commanding officer, U.S. Naval Amphibious Base (Little Creek) 
Commanding officer, U.S. Naval Air Station (Oceana) 
Commanding officer, U.S. Fleet Combat Training Center—Atlantic (Dam Neck) 
Commanding officer, Headquarters—Fort Story 
Commanding officer, Fleet Marine Force-Atlantic 
Site commander, Virginia Army National Guard 
The military liaison commission shall meet formally and/or informally on a regular semiannual basis to communicate with each governmental entity, provide good public relations, and create a better understanding of military regulations, civilian laws and community interests. 
(Ord. No. 1797, 8-1-88; Ord. No. 1800, 8-15-88; Ord. No. 1803, 8-22-88) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1797, adopted August 1, 1988, as amended by Ord. No. 1800 and Ord. No. 1803, added § 2-442 to the Code. Inasmuch as a § 2-442 had been previously added by Ord. No. 1792, adopted July 11, 1988, § 2-442 added by Ord. No. 1797 has been redesignated as § 2-452 herein, at the discretion of the editor. See also the editor's note to the title of this Art. XXII.  
Sec. 2-452.1. - Chesapeake Bay Preservation Area Board. 
(a)  There is hereby created the Chesapeake Bay Preservation Area Board, which shall have such authority as is conferred upon it by the provisions of the Chesapeake Bay Preservation Area Ordinance. Such board shall consist of nine (9) members, who shall be appointed by the city council for terms of three (3) years; provided, however, that original appointments shall be made as follows: Three (3) members shall be appointed for a term of three (3) years, two (2) members for a term of two (2) years, and two (2) members for a term of one (1) year. Members may serve for no more than three (3) consecutive three-year terms in addition to an initial term, if such initial term is less than three (3) years, but a member whose term expires shall continue to serve until his successor is appointed and qualifies. Appointments to fill vacancies shall be for the unexpired portion of the term. Members of the board shall be appointed on a volunteer basis and shall be reimbursed for their necessary expenses in discharging their duties. 
(b)  The board shall elect from its membership a chair and vice-chair. The chair shall preside at all meetings of the board, except that the vice-chair shall preside in the absence of the chair. Members of the board shall be required to take an oath of office prior to assuming their positions. The board may make, alter and rescind rules and forms for its procedures, consistent with the ordinances of the city, including, without limitation, Sections 110 and 111 of the Chesapeake Bay Preservation Area Ordinance, and the general laws of the commonwealth. 
(c)  Pursuant to the provisions of section 2.2-3115(A) of the Code of Virginia, the members of the Chesapeake Bay Preservation Area Board, as a condition of assuming office, shall file disclosure statements of their personal interests and other information specified on the forms set forth in Code of Virginia section 2.2-3117 and, thereafter, file such statements annually in accordance with the provisions of Code of Virginia section 2.2-3115(A). 
(Ord. No. 2012, 11-6-90; Ord. No. 2021, 12-11-90; Ord. No. 2028, 1-8-91; Ord. No. 2301, 12-6-94; Ord. No. 2435, 1-7-97; Ord. No. 2792, 12-9-03; Ord. No. 3286, 5-14-13; Ord. No. 3364, 7-8-14; Ord. No. 3539, 4-3-18) 
Cross reference— Chesapeake Bay Preservation Area Ordinance, App. F.  
Sec. 2-452.2. - Board of zoning appeals. 
(a)  The board of zoning appeals shall consist of seven (7) regular members and a maximum of three (3) alternates appointed by the city council. Members and alternates shall be appointed for terms of five (5) years, except that appointments to fill vacancies shall be only for the unexpired portion of the term, and members and alternates may be reappointed to succeed themselves. The qualifications, organization and procedures of the board shall be as set forth in sections 15.2-2308 through 15.2-2314 of the Code of Virginia, as amended. 
(b)  The accumulation of more than three (3) absences of a member within a given calendar year for reasons other than personal illness, the illness or death of a relative, or other circumstances beyond such member's control shall constitute grounds for removal of such member. 
(c)  The board shall make, alter or rescind rules and guidelines for its procedures consistent with the ordinances of the city and laws of the Commonwealth of Virginia. 
(d)  On or about July 1 of each year, or as soon thereafter as is reasonably practicable, the members of the board, including alternates, shall collectively meet with the city attorney in order to review the duties and responsibilities of the board and the laws and procedures pertaining to matters coming before the board. The members of the board may also, at their option, attend the Virginia Certified Boards of Zoning Appeals Program sponsored by the Virginia Cooperative Extension Service. 
(Ord. No. 2548, 7-6-99; Ord. No. 2554, 7-13-99; Ord. No. 2718, 8-6-02)
