Chapter 5 - ANIMALS AND FOWL[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Animals on beach and adjacent areas, § 6-5; riding horses on beach or dunes, § 6-12; applicability of traffic regulations to persons riding or driving animals, § 21-15; noisy animals, § 23-47(a)(2); interfering with police animals, § 27-7. 
State Law reference— General authority of city to regulate animals and fowl, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-870. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 5-100. - Violations. 
Unless otherwise specifically provided, a violation of any provision of this chapter shall constitute a class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 3072, 3-24-09)  
Sec. 5-101. - Enforcement of this chapter. 
The provisions of this chapter shall be enforced by the city animal control officers and by city law enforcement officers. 
(Ord. No. 3072, 3-24-09)  
Sec. 5-102. - Definitions. 
All definitions of words and phrases contained in the Code of Virginia § 3.2-6500 are hereby adopted and shall apply to such words and phrases when used in this chapter, unless clearly indicated to the contrary. 
(Ord. No. 3072, 3-24-09)  
Sec. 5-103. - Animal control unit advisory board. 
(a)  The Virginia Beach Animal Control Unit Advisory Board ("advisory board'") shall serve as an advisory board to the Virginia Beach Police Department and shall be vested with the following duties and functions. The committee shall serve as a group of interested community members who will meet on a quarterly basis to provide advice to help sustain and advocate for the operation of the city's Adoption-Friendly Animal Care and Adoption Center ("adoption center") and the animal control unit's enforcement efforts so as to best serve the community. 
(b)  The advisory board shall support the city's animal adoption, animal enforcement and animal sheltering functions and shall enhance the city's relationship with animal care professionals, animal advocacy groups and community members. The advisory board shall provide vision and leadership recommendations to the police department in order to meet the city's present and future animal care needs. 
(Ord. No. 3185, 6-28-11; Ord. No. 3575, 12-11-18)  
Sec. 5-104. - Membership. 
The advisory board shall consist of ten (10) voting members and three (3) nonvoting members, plus two (2) nonvoting city council liaisons. The members shall be appointed by the police department. The ten (10) voting members shall consist of: two (2) Virginia Beach SPCA ("VBSPCA") representatives; two (2) representatives from the external veterinary community; five (5) interested citizens who are not affiliated with any animal welfare groups, and a representative of the Virginia Beach Health Department. When requested in order to fill a VBSPCA vacancy on the advisory Board, the VBSPCA Director shall each submit a list of at least four (4) nominees for appointment by the police department as the representatives of their organization and a selection will be made by the chief of police or his designee. Any of the persons nominated must be current members in good standing of the organization. When a vacancy exists for a member of the external veterinary community or an interested citizen member, a search will be conducted via public outlet to seek interested persons who are in good community standing. Selections will be made by the chief of police or his designee. The adoption center manager, the animal enforcement unit lieutenant and the adoption center veterinarian shall be the three (3) nonvoting members and shall be permanent members of the advisory board. All voting members shall be residents of the City of Virginia Beach and shall be appointed to three-year terms and subject to a term limit of three (3) consecutive three-year terms. 
(Ord. No. 3185, 6-28-11; Ord. No. 3487, 2-21-17; Ord. No. 3575, 12-11-18)  
Sec. 5-105. - Duties. 
The advisory board shall: 
(a)  Serve as the advisory body to the police department on behalf of the community in matters related to animal care by serving as an independent, unbiased sounding board; 
(b)  Serve in an advisory capacity for staff, addressing mission critical service topics and community outreach by helping foster positive relationships with all customers; 
(c)  Provide advisory recommendations to staff to ensure quality care for the animals cared for at the adoption center, including: 
(1)  Advice regarding general animal control issues; 
(2)  Advice regarding the status of rabies in the city and the public health aspect of rabies; 
(3)  Recommendations regarding animal licensing procedures and fees; 
(4)  Advice regarding animal shelter operations in the city; 
(5)  Recommendations regarding field health operations; and 
(6)  Consultations with city staff and public health experts regarding animal issues, culminating with reports of such findings and recommendations to the city manager and city council; 
(d)  Increase awareness of animals available for adoption at the adoption center; 
(e)  Increase awareness of the importance of spaying/neutering animals; 
(f)  Educate the community regarding the humane treatment of animals and other matters related to animal care responsibilities; 
(g)  Provide a forum for public discussion of the animal care unit's efforts to bring about positive change and process improvement; 
(h)  Serve as a means of communication between animal care professionals, animal advocacy groups, community members and municipal staff; 
(i)  Support the animal control unit in its task to provide the best possible care to the animals and quality customer service to the members of the Virginia Beach community; 
(j)  Undertake projects and activities to benefit the animal control unit and the community; 
(k)  Advocate on behalf of the animal control unit in the community; and 
(l)  Provide an annual report to city council. 
(Ord. No. 3185, 6-28-11)  
Secs. 5-106—5-199. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - RABIES 
 
Sec. 5-200. - Vaccination or inoculation of dogs or cats. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to own, keep, hold or harbor any dog or cat over the age of four (4) months within the city, unless such dog or cat is currently vaccinated with a rabies vaccine, licensed by the United States Department of Agriculture for use in that species. If, however, the requirement of vaccination or inoculation threatens the physical well-being of such dog or cat, the owner of such dog or cat shall have a certificate signed by a licensed veterinarian certifying the same and the owner shall keep such dog or cat in quarantine until the same is inoculated or vaccinated. 
(b)  Any person transporting a dog or cat into the city from some other jurisdiction shall comply with this section within thirty (30) days from the day he brings such dog or cat into the city, if such dog or cat is to be kept in the city more than thirty (30) days. 
(c)  The vaccination or inoculation required by this section shall be administered by or under the supervision of a licensed veterinarian. When so administered, the veterinarian shall issue to the owner of the dog or cat a tag and a certificate of rabies inoculation or vaccination, properly executed and signed by the veterinarian, certifying that the dog or cat in question has been inoculated or vaccinated in accordance with the provisions of this section. Such tag shall be firmly attached to the dog's or cat's collar and shall be worn at times when the dog or cat is not on the property of the owner or custodian of the dog or cat. The owner or custodian of the dog or cat shall furnish, within a reasonable period of time, upon request of any animal control officer, law enforcement officer or official of the department of health, the certificate of vaccination for such dog or cat. 
(d)  City council authorizes a rabies clinic to be conducted at least once every two (2) years, and the animal control division shall ensure that the clinic is conducted in conformance with the requirements of Code of Virginia § 3.2-6521. 
(Ord. No. 3072, 3-24-09; Ord. No. 3292, 6-11-13, eff. 7-1-13)  
Sec. 5-201. - Report of existence of rabid animals. 
Every person having knowledge of the existence of an animal apparently afflicted with rabies shall report immediately to the local health department the existence of such animal, the place where seen, the owner's name, if known, and the symptoms suggesting rabies. 
(Ord. No. 3072, 3-24-09)  
Sec. 5-202. - Report of animal bites of human beings. 
All animal bites of human beings shall be reported to the department of public health within twenty-four (24) hours after occurrence. Such report shall include the name and post office address of the person bitten, the owner of the biting animal and a reasonable description of the animal. The responsibility of so reporting is mutually charged to attending physicians, veterinarians, owners of the biting animals and persons bitten and any other persons who may have knowledge of such fact. 
(Ord. No. 3072, 3-24-09)  
Sec. 5-203. - Emergency ordinance. 
Where there is sufficient reason to believe a rabid animal is at large city council may pass an emergency ordinance as provided in Code of Virginia § 3.2-6522. 
(Ord. No. 3072, 3-24-09)  
Sec. 5-204. - Confinement or destruction of dogs, cats and other animals showing signs of or suspected of having rabies. 
Any dog, cat or other animal found within the city showing active signs of rabies or suspected of having rabies shall be confined under competent observation for such time as may be necessary to determine a diagnosis. If confinement is impossible or impracticable, such dog, cat or other animal shall be euthanized by one of the methods authorized in Code of Virginia § 3.2-6546. 
(Ord. No. 3072, 3-24-09)  
Sec. 5-205. - Destruction or confinement of dog or cat bitten by rabid animal. 
(a)  Any dog or cat, for which no proof of current rabies vaccination is available and that is exposed to rabies by an animal believed to be afflicted with rabies, shall be confined in a pound, kennel or enclosure approved by the health department for a period not to exceed six (6) months at the expense of the owner. An inactivated rabies vaccine may be administered at the beginning of the confinement. A rabies vaccination shall be administered prior to release. If this is not feasible, the dog or cat shall be humanely euthanized. 
(b)  Any dog or cat, for which there is proof of a valid rabies vaccination and that is exposed to rabies by an animal believed to be afflicted with rabies shall be revaccinated immediately following the bite and shall be confined to the premises of the owner, or other site as may be approved by the health department, for a period of forty-five (45) days. 
(c)  When any animals, other than a dog or cat, is exposed to rabies by an animal believed to be afflicted with rabies, that newly exposed animal shall be confined at the discretion of and in a manner approved by the health director, or euthanized. 
(Ord. No. 3072, 3-24-09)  
Sec. 5-206. - Confinement or destruction of animal which has bitten person. 
(a)  At the discretion of the director of public health, any animal which has bitten a person shall be confined under competent observation for ten (10) days, unless the animal develops active symptoms of rabies or expires before that time; provided, that a seriously injured or sick animal may be humanely euthanized and its head sent to the health department for evaluation. 
(b)  At the discretion of the director of health, any potentially rabid animal, other than a dog or cat, that exposes or may have exposed a person to rabies shall be confined in a manner approved by the health department or humanely euthanized and its head sent to the health department for evaluation. 
(Ord. No. 3072, 3-24-09)  
Sec. 5-207. - Concealing or harboring animal to prevent its destruction or confinement under article. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to conceal or harbor any dog, cat or other animal to keep the same from being destroyed or confined in accord with this article. 
(Ord. No. 3072, 3-24-09)  
Secs. 5-208—5-299. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - LOCAL LICENSES 
 
Sec. 5-300. - License required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to own a dog or cat four (4) months old or older in this city, unless such dog or cat is licensed under the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 3072, 3-24-09)  
Sec. 5-301. - Application; applicant to be city resident. 
(a)  Any person may obtain a one-, two-, or three-year city dog or cat license by making oral or written application to the city treasurer or an appointed agent, accompanied by the amount of the license tax and the evidence of vaccination required by section 5-306. 
(b)  Additionally, any person obtaining a rabies vaccination from a vet-agent as provided in section 5-302 below may obtain a one-, two-, or three-year local license that runs concurrently with the vaccination administered by paying the tax as provided in section 5-303. The vet-agent shall only have authority to license dogs and cats of resident owners or custodians who reside within the city. 
(c)  Any person purchasing a dog or cat license shall provide residency information to the city treasurer or the appointed agent. It shall be unlawful for any person to make any false statement in or present any false evidence with an application submitted under this section, in order to secure a dog or cat license to which such person is not entitled. 
(d)  A one-year license tag shall be valid for up to twelve (12) months from the date of issue, not to exceed the duration of the current rabies vaccination; a two-year license tag shall be valid for up to twenty-four (24) months from the date of issue, not to exceed the duration of the current rabies vaccination; and a three-year license tag shall be valid for up to thirty-six (36) months, not to exceed the duration of the current rabies vaccination. 
(Ord. No. 3072, 3-24-09)  
Sec. 5-302. - Veterinarians as appointed agents. 
(a)  The city treasurer may appoint agents for the collection of the license tax and the issuance of the license tags. Any veterinarian who vaccinates or supervises the vaccination of dogs and cats against rabies and is licensed to do business in Virginia Beach may submit an application to the city treasurer for such an agent appointment. 
(b)  The vet-agent shall have authority to issue local license tags on those occasions where he or she is presented with a current rabies certificate or when administering rabies vaccinations to dogs or cats of owners or custodians who reside within the city. The issued local tag shall run concurrently with the vaccination administered or in conjunction with the current certificate. The vet-agent shall collect the required fee as outlined below in section 5-303. The fee and the required report shall be submitted to the city treasurer as provided in the written agreement required in subsection (d) below. 
(c)  For every one-, two-, or three-year local license tag issued, the vet-agent shall deduct one dollar ($1.00) from the amount due to the city treasurer. 
(d)  Each appointed vet-agent shall agree in writing to abide by procedures and protocols established by the city treasurer. Any vet-agent who fails to follow the established procedures or protocols may have his or her authority to collect the license taxes and issue the license tags revoked by the city treasurer.  
Sec. 5-303. - Tax imposed. 
(a)  A license tax is hereby imposed on dogs and cats required to be licensed under this article in the following nonrefundable amounts: 
(1)  For each dog or cat, not spayed or not neutered: 
1-year tag .....$10.00 
2-year tag .....$20.00 
3-year tag .....$30.00 
(2)  For each dog, spayed or neutered: 
1-year tag .....$7.00 
2-year tag .....$14.00 
3-year tag .....$21.00 
(3)  For each cat, spayed or neutered: 
1-year tag .....$5.00 
2-year tag .....$10.00 
3-year tag .....$15.00 
(4)  Kennel of five (5) to twenty (20) dogs, or five (5) to twenty (20) cats, annually .....$35.00 
(5)  Kennel of twenty-one (21) or more dogs, or of twenty-one (21) or more cats, annually .....$50.00 
Pursuant to Code of Virginia § 3.2-6500, a "kennel" is any establishment in which five or more canines, felines, or hybrids of either are kept for the purpose of breeding, hunting, training, renting, buying, boarding, selling, or showing. The owner of a kennel or cattery shall pay the kennel or cattery tax imposed above but shall not be required to also pay the individual dog or cat license fees listed in subsections (1) and (2) for any dog or cat that is owned by the owner of the kennel or cattery and that is housed within the kennel or cattery. 
(b)  A license tax in the nonrefundable amount of fifty dollars ($50.00) is hereby imposed on pet shops, annually.* [] 
Pursuant to Code of Virginia § 3.2-6500, a "pet shop" is a retail establishment where companion animals are bought, sold, exchanged, or offered for sale or exchange to the general public. 
(c)  A quarterly prorated license tax shall be imposed on any dog or cat owner when he or she moves to Virginia Beach or purchases, adopts, or otherwise acquires a dog or cat that has a current rabies vaccination. This prorated fee may only be imposed by the staff at the office of the city treasurer, and no prorated fee may be offered by appointed agents authorized by section 5-302. The prorated fee shall be based on date of residence or date of purchase as compared to the date of rabies expiration. Verification of these dates must be provided at time of licensing. Quarterly prorated license fee shall be determined based upon the amount of time remaining before the rabies vaccination expires. The quarterly prorated fee shall be as follows: 
(1)  Twenty-five (25) percent of the annual fee if at least one (1) month, but less than four (4) months, remain before expiration of the vaccination. 
(2)  Fifty (50) percent of the annual fee if at least four (4) months, but less than seven (7) months, remain before expiration of the vaccination. 
(3)  Seventy-five (75) percent of the annual fee if at least seven (7) months, but less than ten (10) months, remain before expiration of the vaccination. 
(4)  One hundred (100) percent of the annual fee if at least ten (10) months remain before expiration of vaccination. 
(d)  A quarterly prorated license fee shall be imposed on any dog or cat owner having a valid rabies certificate issued between January 3, 2005 and September 30, 2007. The prorated fee shall be based on the time remaining on January 1, 2008 and the expiration of the rabies certificate. Quarterly prorated fees shall be imposed only on portions of years, and shall be imposed as follows: 
(1)  Twenty-five (25) percent of the annual fee if at least one month, but less than four (4) months, remain before expiration of the vaccination. 
(2)  Fifty (50) percent of the annual fee if at least four (4) months, but less than seven (7) months, remain before expiration of the vaccination. 
(3)  Seventy-five (75) percent of the annual fee if at least seven (7) months, but less than ten (10) months, remain before expiration of the vaccination. 
(4)  One hundred (100) percent of the annual fee if at least ten (10) months remain before expiration of vaccination. 
(e)  No license tax shall be levied under this section on any dog that is trained and serves as a guide dog for a blind person, that is trained and serves as a hearing dog for a deaf or hearing-impaired person, or that is trained and serves as a service dog for a mobility-impaired person. For the purposes of this subsection, a "hearing dog" is a dog trained to alert its owner, by touch, to sounds of danger and sounds to which the owner should respond, and a "service dog" means a dog trained to accompany its owner for the purpose of carrying items, retrieving objects, pulling a wheelchair or other such activities of service or support. 
(f)  Any person who applies for a license tag for a neutered or spayed dog or cat shall present, at the time of application, an appropriate veterinarian's certification suitable to the city treasurer attesting to the neutering or spaying of the dog or cat. If such certification is not so presented, the dog or cat shall be taxed the fee levied on unneutered and unspayed dogs or cats. 
(Ord. No. 3072, 3-24-09; Ord. No. 3563, 7-3-18, eff. 1-1-19) 
Footnotes:
